Earlier, she used to weave through yarn supplied by middlemen and hence could not garner enough profit to manage her household expenses. As she could earn only the fee for the labour, while the maximum profit from the activity was taken away by the middleman, she decided to weave on her own.

She wants to expand her weaving business by purchasing more yarn. Similarly, the other members of the group are also facing a shortage of working capital to expand their businesses. So, they decided to form the group and apply for a loan to enhance their income-earning capacity. They are together seeking a loan of INR 140,000 (20,000 each) to expand their businesses.

They are well aware of group rules and agreed to abide by them, and are thankful to the lenders for their support.

loans.use: to purchase yarn to expand her weaving business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be innovative.

She operates a M-pesa business. Her business is located in a prime area, and her primary customers are individuals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient capital.

She will use the KES 80,000 loan to add M-pesa float.

Her business goal is to open more M-pesa outlets within five years. This is her fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to add M-pesa float.

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
When speaking to Elijah, it's hard not to notice that he is a farmer who was born and raised in challenging conditions. He is a smallholder farmer from a village in Mugiriro, located in the central region of Kenya. He owns a tranquil, rustic farmstead where he lives with his spouse and two children. For the last ten years Elijah has been practising mixed farming - growing maize and keeping dairy cattle. Elijah also has a side hustle business that he does to supplement the meager income he earns from farming.

Some time back, Elijah joined a Njeruni group composed of mostly marginalized farmers who could not secure loans from formal financial institutions. Through the group, they secured loans from Juhudi Kilimo through a group-based guarantee mechanism. Group members are a source of encouragement and empowerment to each other. After being successfully registered into the company, they went through a training of basic financial and business skills.

Elijah has applied for a loan of 30,000 KES to purchase poultry. He is looking to venture into poultry farming. With time, he will expand. Income generated from these investments will enable him to meet high farming expenses. He stated that his family will also get to enjoy all the benefits that come along with increased income.

Elijah's dream is that he will have good health so that he can work hard and secure the future of his children.

loans.use: to purchase poultry

loans.name: Awa's Group

texts.fr:
Mme AWA est responsable du groupe RAYI-ZALLEM 02 SAPONE. Elle  mariée et mère de 05 enfants. Le plus âgé a 18 ans et le moins âgé a 02 ans. 04 enfants vont à l’école et elle a 07 personnes en charges.
Mme est vendeuse de céréales depuis 19 ans. Elle s’approvisionne dans les marchés environnants.
Avec l’argent octroyé, elle compte acheter  01 sac de mil.
Elle veut utiliser les bénéfices du prêt pour réinvestir dans son activité. Elle ambitionne assurer la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Ms. AWA is responsible for the Rayi-Zallem 02 Sapone group. She is the married mother of five children, the eldest of whom is 18 years old and the youngest is under two. Four of the children go to school and she has seven persons to care for.

She has been a vendor of grain cereals for the past 19 years, and resupplies in surrounding markets. With the money granted, she intends to buy one bag of millet.

She wants to reinvest profits from the loan in her business, and aims to ensure her children's education.

loans.use: use the money granted to buy one bag of millet

loans.name: Rayi-Sallem 01 Sapone Group

texts.fr:
Mme PAULINE est responsable du groupe RAYI-ZALLEM 01 SAPONE. Elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants. Le plus âgé a 18 ans  et le moins âgé a 1 ans. 05 enfants vont à l’école et elle  a 08 personnes en charge.
Mme est vendeuse de céréales depuis 19 ans. Elle s’approvisionne dans les marchés environnants.
Avec l’argent octroyé, elle compte acheter 03 sacs de céréales.
Elle veut utiliser les bénéfices du prêt pour réinvestir dans son activité. Elle ambitionne assurer la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Ms. Pauline is responsible for the Rayi-Zallem 01 Sapone group. She is the married mother of six children, the eldest of whom is 18 years old and the youngest less than one year. Five of the children go to school and she has eight persons to care for.

She has been a vendor of grain cereals for the past 19 years, and gets her supplies from surrounding markets. With the money granted, she intends to buy three bags of grain.

She wants to reinvest profits from the loan in her business, and aims to ensure her children's education.

loans.use: use the money granted to buy three bags of cereal

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Hello world, meet Gladys, a smallholder farmer from the Lelan area of Kenya where farming is the mainstay of rural economy. Gladys has been doing farming for 5 years to provide for her family, which consists of her, her husband and 4 children.

The challenge is that human labour is still the main source of power used in agricultural work in Lelan. In small-scale farms like Gladys’, human labor comes with high cost because the basic wage rate is high, and people are neither easy to manage nor as efficient as machines.

Gladys is seeking a loan to buy new farm implements that will cut costs and improve the efficiency, productivity and profitability of her farm. Part of the income generated from this investment will be rolled back into the business to drive growth and the rest will be used to meet family needs.

loans.use: to buy farm implements

loans.name: Girimana Group

texts.fr:
Souavis  fait partie du groupe  Girimana et  habite à  Gitega. Elle a 39 ans et est mariée à Cassien, un commerçant. Ensemble ils ont 7 enfants âgés de 6 à 18 ans, dont  6 étudient. 

Elle fait le commerce de s habits et des planches  depuis  10 ans. 

Elle est à son cinquième   crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’elle obtient, elle  va  augmenter son capital et acheter  une grande quantité  de haricot    à revendre pour gagner plus.
texts.en:
Souavis is part of the Girimana group and lives in Gitega. She is 39 years old and is married to Cassian, a merchant. Together they have seven children from 6 to 18 years of age, of whom six attend school.

She has been trading clothes and boards for the past ten years.

This is her fifth credit loan with Turame, and she will use the Kiva loan to increase her working capital and buy a large amount of beans for resale, to earn more.

loans.use: increase her working capital and buy a large amount of beans for resale, to earn more.

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Many people in Kenya are poor and most of them find an opportunity in farming to make a living and progress through practicing mixed farming. Such is the case of Samwel who, at the age of 40, has gone through many adversities but has always put on a brave face.

Samwel resides in a remote village in the Kitale area of Kenya. He is elegant and admirable in spirit and effort. He is a role model, a mentor and an inspiration to many young farmers in his village because of his resilience despite personal challenges and his passion to support his children as a primary caregiver. The living conditions in the Kitale area are very tough and you need to have tough skin in order to survive. Samwel has always shown the resilience to beat all odds. Because of the hardcore poverty in his village, Samwel started practicing mixed farming 10 years ago. His sources of income are vegetables, milk, and egg sales. However, these products are very perishable and require timely delivery to the market. The Kitale area has a poor road network and poor feeder roads that really hamper timely delivery of products to the market; that is why Samwel is kindly seeking a loan to buy a motorbike. With the motorbike, he will deliver products to the market on time and reap more profits because the products will still be fresh.

Samwel is very determined to succeed. Because he is much disciplined with finances, he plans that he will be able to provide a secure future for himself and for his children through accumulated profits. Samwel's dream is to provide a secure future for his children by paying tuition fees for them. You will help him realize his dream through your loan.

For Samwel, nothing is impossible. He wants to continue working to fulfill his dream of becoming the lead supplier of farm produce in his village.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to deliver his products to the market in a timely manner.

loans.name: Carmen Silvia

texts.es:
Carmen es una mujer de 48 años de edad, casada, tiene un hijo de 22 años y una hija de 17, y su negocio es la venta de joyas y productos para el hogar.
Ella es buena madre, sincera, comprensiva, constante, responsable y muy trabajadora. Su negocio lo realiza en la zona ‘Pampahasi’, ubicado al norte de la ciudad, al pie de las faldas del cerro donde las calles son pendientes y empinadas. De clima frio y seco con una temperatura que varía durante el día entre 0-12 grados centígrados.
Carmen es de tez trigueña, ojos pardos, cabello castaño largo, baja estatura, complexión física robusta, su lengua materna es el Aymará que habla en familia y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza. Su vida la comparte con su esposo que es militar y con sus hijos; el mayor estudia y trabaja y la menor estudia en la escuela, viven en un cuarto propio construido de ladrillo y cemento con techo de calamina y piso de madera que cuenta con energía eléctrica, agua potable y alcantarillado. Sus deseos de superación por la necesidad de ayudar con los gastos universitarios de su hijo mayor, la llevó a solicitar un crédito para mejorar su negocio. Su negocio es la venta ambulante de joyas de acero quirúrgico como, aretes, anillos, collares, etc., y artículos para el hogar como; carteras, adornos, juegos de cubiertos, y otros, “el oro y la plata pueden provocar reacciones alérgicas en algunas personas, lo cual no ocurre con el acero quirúrgico, además, es inoxidable y resiste sustancias como el cloro, agua, jabones y perfumes…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que sus joyas son relativamente nuevas y el público es innovador, la desventaja es la falta de capital para la compra de joyas quirúrgicas por mayor. Su sueño es incrementar su capital de trabajo para mejorar sus ofertas, ella desea realizar la compra de joyas quirúrgicas por mayor para ofertar mayor variedad a sus clientes. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 4 años que se dedica a asta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Carmen solicita un préstamo para la compra de joyas quirúrgicas por mayor para obtener mejores ingresos y ayudar con los gastos universitarios de su hijo.
texts.en:
Carmen is a 48-year-old woman. She is married and has a 22-year-old son and a 17-year-old daughter. Her business is selling jewelry and household products. She is a good mother, sincere, understanding, steadfast, responsible, and very hard-working. She carries out her business in the Pampahasi area located just north of the city at the foot of the skirts of the hill where the streets are sloping and steep. It has a cold and dry climate with a temperature that varies daily from 0-12 degrees centigrade.

Carmen has brown skin, grayish-brown eyes, and long brown hair. She is short and has a robust physique. Her native language us the Aymará that she speaks with her family, but she speaks Spanish for general purposes and for the work that she does. She shares her life with her husband, who is in the military, and their children; the eldest studies and works, and the youngest attends school. They live in their own little house made of brick and cement. It has a corrugated steel roof and a wood floor, as well as electricity, potable water, and a sewage system.

Her desire to overcome and the need to help with the university expenses of her oldest child led her to ask for a loan to improve her business. She works as a street vendor selling stainless steel jewelry like earrings, rings, necklaces, etc.; and articles for the home like purses, ornaments, silverware, and other items. "The gold and the silver can provoke allergic reactions in some people, which does not happen with stainless steel. Additionally, it does not rust and it resists substances like chlorine, water, soap, and perfumes…," she says.

An advantage to her business is that her jewelry is relatively new and the public is innovative. A disadvantage is her lack of capital in order to buy the stainless steel jewelry at wholesale. Her dream is to increase her working capital in order to improve her sales, and she wishes to purchase wholesale stainless steel jewelry so that she can offer a larger variety to her customers.

This is her first cycle of loans with the institution in the four years that she has dedicated herself to this work. It is for these reasons that Carmen asks for the loan to buy wholesale stainless steel jewelry in order to get a better income and help with her son's university expenses.

loans.use: to buy wholesale stainless steel jewelry in order to get a better income and help with her son's university expenses.

loans.name: Justin

texts.en:
Justin has an entrepreneurial spirit, is active, vibrant, and constantly struggles to be able to get ahead. Justin is extremely hardworking, only taking Sundays off so that he can spend time with his family.

He is based in Magutuni, a remote village in the Chuka area of Kenya, which is an area with high poultry production and consumption. For five years, he has been actively involved in mixed farming as a source of income. He has a beautiful and supportive wife who helps him with his farm work and domestic chores.

His primary source of income is from milk, maize, and some personal business that he does to make ends meet. He passionately loves poultry farming, and this can be noticed in how he takes good care of his poultry birds and feeds them. When asked what he enjoys about poultry farming, he replied that he enjoys “picking the eggs every day in the morning.” However, this humble and honest man faces challenges of not meeting the demand for eggs and also not satisfying his ever-increasing client base. That is why he is requesting a loan to buy good-quality breeds of poultry.

Poultry farming is a very profitable business venture and the demand for chicken is always high, being such a popular meal for so many people. Other than increased profits, he will benefit from poultry manure; hence saving more money that could have been used in buying fertilizer. Through increased income from eggs, and selling poultry meat and feathers, he will permanently change his living conditions and secure the future of his school-going children.

With your support, this man will be able to achieve his dreams. Loan today!

loans.use: to buy good-quality breeds of poultry.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is 42 years old. She is married and a housewife. She is illiterate, but can sign her name only. She is blessed with three grownup sons. At present, one of them is engaged in a vegetable business, another is working in a shop, and the youngest one is jobless. They live in a remote region of Falakata in Alipurduar district in their own mud and straw-made house.

Anita's husband Amar is 49 years old and a farmer by profession. He mainly grows vegetables like potatoes, gourds, ladies fingers, beans, etc. He grows quality products, and his prices are also cheaper. So, the numbers of his customers are increasing gradually. Now he wants to cultivate teasel gourd on his farmland.

Thus, Anita is requesting a loan to buy teasel gourd seeds, pesticide, fertilizer, etc. to grow teasel gourd. She will use a part of loan amount to bear the operational cost throughout the year. They hope that with this loan amount, they will have a good harvest. With the profit from this business, they hope they can secure their lives in terms of food, health, and education.

Anita dreams to build a concrete house with the profit from their business in the future. She is thankful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs for teasel gourd cultivation.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
The lady in the photo is Stella. She is 25 years old.

She is a teacher and also practices maize farming. Having undergone Hand in Hand Eastern Africa training on savings and enterprise development, her skills in business management have improved.

She is borrowing a loan from Kiva, with which she intends to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer that will help in improving productivity. This will help her meet family needs with ease.

She is very grateful to Kiva for the support and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizer that will help in improving productivity.

loans.name: Salina

texts.en:
Salina is an experienced 45-year-old woman. She is a person who has battled to get ahead throughout her life. She is based in Kapsowar, which is a small rural town in the north rift of Kenya. Salina and her husband have been blessed with a lovely family.

For 10 years Salina has been a mixed farmer. She keeps dairy cattle and poultry on her farm. She also grows maize, among other crops. Despite prevailing animal diseases, she finds dairy farming to be the most enjoyable commercial farming activity. Besides dairy farming, she has a deep connection with gardening. In African communities, gardening is the most popular, yet the least exclusive hobby for women. You really don't have to be born with a green thumb to give life to a glorious garden; any woman with a homestead and a few square feet of earth is doing her best to make her little corner of the world more gracious and beautiful. Salina, however, is taking this a little step further. Salina is seeking a loan to buy seeds and start horticultural farming. This is a big deal for her. She is very excited to start growing different varieties of crops for commercial purposes. The demand for vegetables and other greens is always high. Income from this venture will cover the high farming expenses she has to deal with currently. In the long run, with increased income, she will finally be able to satisfy her family’s basic needs.

loans.use: to buy seeds and start horticulture farming.

loans.name: Rodelo

texts.en:
Rodelo is a 32-year-old man from Iloilo, Philippines. He is married and has a one-year-old daughter. Rodelo and his wife have been running a printing sho for four years. They work hard to have better ways of living.

Rodelo is a asking for a loan of PHP 15,000 to buy printing materials such as plastic, ceramics and wax. He also wants to buy t-shirts and a tarp. In the future, Rodelo wants to expand his business. He was planning to add another branch to his business to increase their livelihood.

loans.use: to buy plastic, ceramics, wax, t-shirts and a tarp

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, 55 years old, is married and supports four children. He is a small scale farmer.

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase certified fertilizers, herbicides and pesticides to spray his crops for quality production. 

He plans to use the gained profits to repay his loan and buy a dairy cow to supplement his farming activity. He hopes to improve his family living standards.

loans.use: to purchase certified fertilizers, herbicides and pesticides to spray his crops for quality production.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Janice

texts.en:
Hello, lenders, please meet Janice. Born in 1985, Janice has grown into a strong and independent woman. She has been able to hold her family of three children together and provide for them, after she separated from her husband. She is a mixed farmer, who grows maize and vegetables for both consumption and sale. She also runs a small business.

Janice is seeking a loan, with which she intends to purchase a high-quality dairy cow. The dairy business is very profitable in this area. Most families rely on milk to feed their children and prepare their meals. Ugali is the staple food of people from the Chuka area of Kenya, where Mitheru village lies. Ugali is tasteless, as it is made from pure maize flour and water. To make this into a mouthwatering delicacy, it has to be accompanied by sour milk and well-cooked vegetables, and meat for those who can afford it. Milk is also an ingredient in the preparation of vegetables. The heavy reliance on milk allows dairy farmers to do well in this region. Milk prices are always high because of the high demand. Little product marketing is required here, because milk is milk.

With your loan, Janice will not only reduce the amount of money she must spend on milk for the family, but also she will increase her income from the sale of milk. She will use the profits to grow the business and to keep supporting her family.

loans.use: to buy a high-quality dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy iron, cement, stone, wire, and nails to continue with a construction project.

loans.name: Nazgul

texts.ru: Назгул, 41 год, замужем, есть 2 сыновей и дочь. У нее среднее образование. В качестве дохода она занимается животноводством и полеводством. В хозяйстве есть 2 коровы, 2 овцы. На 1,23 Га земли выращивает кукурузу и помидоры для реализации. Ежемесячный доход около 15,800 сом (KGS). Назгул обратилась в Банк «Бай – Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку строительных материалов для постройки сарая для скота. Доходы от бизнеса она направит на развитие бизнеса.
texts.en:
Nazgul is 41, married, and the mother of two sons and a daughter. She has a secondary education. She is involved in animal husbandry and agriculture, two activities which constitute a source of income for her family. She has two cows and two sheep on her farm. She grows corn and tomatoes for resale on 1.23 hectares of land, and makes close to 15,800 som (KGS) per month.

Nazgul has turned to Bai Tushum and requested a loan of 50,000 som (KGS) to buy construction supplies in order to build a barn for her livestock. She will use the earnings from her loan to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy construction materials to build a barn for her livestock.

loans.name: Berta

texts.pt:
A cliente Berta é casada, trabalhadora como técnica agro pecuária  e  comerciante vendendo produtos diversos, mãe de 2 filhos dos quais 1 frequenta o ensino primário e 1 ainda sem idade escolar, vive na casa própria.
Com o valor do empréstimo pretende comprar de diversos tipos de  cerveja e vinhos para reforçar o seu negocio .
A cliente tem como sonho ampliar o seu negocio para responder as necessidades dos seus clientes, construir um talho e uma capoeira para a criação e venda de frangos.
Tem como principais desafios financeiros e a falta de meio para fazer entrega dos seus produtos tem estado a trabalhar e pretende tomar mais vezes o crédito para suprir as dificuldades e alcançar os seus sonhos
texts.en:
Berta is married with two children, one of whom is in elementary school and one of whom is not yet of school age. Her family lives in their own home and she works as a technician at a commercial fish production operation and also in sales, selling a variety of products.

With this loan, Berta plans to buy a variety of beers and wines in order to improve her sales business. Her plans for the future are to expand her business to meet the needs of her customers and to build a chicken coop where she can raise chickens for sale. Her main challenges have been a lack of financing and lack of a means of transport for delivering her products. Berta has been working and she plans to take out more loans in the future in order to overcome any obstacles and make her dreams a reality.

loans.use: buy various types of beer and wine in order to improve her business.

loans.name: Kumushai

texts.ru: Кумушай, 28 лет, не замужем. Образование-среднее, много лет занимается сельским хозяйством- животноводством и полеводством. На сегодняшний день в хозяйстве есть 2 коровы. Ежемесячный доход Кумушай составляет около 16,000 сом (KGS), этих средств не хватает на достойную жизнь, так как сельское хозяйство это единственный источник дохода ее семьи, Кумушай обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку 2 коров для откорма и реализации. Доходы от кредита Кумушай планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение поголовья скота, что позволит улучшить благосостояние семьи Кумушай.
texts.en:
Kumushai is 28 and single. She has a secondary education and has been involved in farming (agriculture and animal husbandry) for many years. She currently has two cows on her farm and she makes a monthly income of about 16,000 som (KGS), which is still insufficient for a decent life.

Since agriculture constitutes her family's only source of income, Kumushai has turned to Bai Tushum and requested a loan of 50,000 som (KGS) to buy two cows for fattening and resale. She is planning to use the earnings from her loan to further increase her cattle headcount, which will allow her to improve her family's well-being.

loans.use: to purchase two cows for fattening and resale.

loans.name: Castro

texts.pt:
O cliente Castro de 58 anos de idade é casado, trabalhador como segurança , pai de 7 filhos dos quais 3 frequentam o ensino secundário, 2 já concluíram o nível médio e 2 ainda sem idade escolar, vive na casa própria.
Com o valor do empréstimo pretende  comprar, ferro, cimento, pedra, pregos, arame, chapas de zinco para dar continuidade da sua obra .
A cliente tem como sonho, concluir a sua casa para oferecer um lar melhor a sua família, construir dependências em sua casa para aumentar a renda familiar .
Tem como principais desafios financeiros tem estado a trabalhar e pretende tomar mais vezes o crédito para suprir as dificuldades e alcançar os seus sonhos
texts.en:
Castro is 58 years old and is married with seven children. Three of his children are currently in high school, two have finished school, and two are not yet in school. He and his family live in their own home.

With this loan, Castro plans to buy iron, cement, stone, nails, wire and zinc plates in order to continue with a construction project. His dream is to finish construction of his home in order to offer his family a better living situation and also to build auxiliary buildings on his property that he can rent out to supplement the family's income. His main challenges have been financial ones but he has been working and he hopes to take out further loans in order to overcome obstacles and to make his dreams a reality.

loans.use: buy iron, cement, stone, nails, wire and zinc plates in order to continue with a construction project.

loans.name: Hoeurn

texts.en:
Hoeurn, 37, is a farmer living in Kandal province and she has six children. She has grown rice and fed cows for sale as the main source of her income for around thirteen years. To overcome her family’s hardships, her husband drives a three-wheel vehicle for a fee to supplement her income.

Hoeurn, has been with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) for nine loan cycles already and she has repaid her past loans successfully. She can better support her living conditions than before as a result of her previous loans.

Due to spending much money on curing her sick child, she does not have enough working capital to support her current business now. She is applying for a new loan of 5,000,000 KHR to buy more cows to raise for sale. She hopes that she will be able to earn more income to update her lifestyle.

loans.use: to buy more cows to raise for sale.

loans.name: Isaki

texts.en:
Isaki is 57 years old. He lives in the Akhmeta district with his wife Nunu. Both of them do physical work and get a daily income.

Isaki decided to start a husbandry business as he has experience in this field. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo enables him to get a loan of GEL 1500 to purchase a cow. Isaki and Nunu will start producing dairy products to sell at a good price. This will increase their income.

Isaki is very hardworking man and hopes that the husbandry business will be profitable for his family. He awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase a cow and start an animal husbandry business.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Kenyan farmers struggle to make their way in the world because of unemployment and lack of capital. This is true for Julius, who is based in the Kapsowar area of Kenya, and is a father of a lovely family. He has been practicing mixed farming for the past five years. He has managed to earn a decent income. His primary source of income has been milk, eggs, crops and some personal business he engages in, to make that extra coin.

Julius enjoys the farming lifestyle. He has a connection with farm animals that goes deep, to the extent that he names each of them. He has aspirations of expanding his dairy farm, but due to financial constraints, he has been unable to do so until now. From Kiva lenders, Julius is kindly requesting KES 42,400 to purchase a high-yielding dairy cow. This cow will boost milk production on the farm. As a result, he will have a greater quantity for both consumption and sales.

With the money from the additional sales, he will be able to service his loan on time. With increased income from the loan, Julius plans to spend money to settle the high farming costs of production. Many farmers compromise quality because of the high cost of inputs. However, with increased income, Julius will not take such measures. In the long run, his family will realize an improved standard of living.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a quality dairy cow

loans.name: Eulalia

texts.es:
Doña Eulalia  es una mujer muy trabajadora tiene 44 años de edad y está casada con el señor Eulalio desde hace 24 años, juntos han formado una familia con cuatro hijos de los cuales solo uno estudia su educación secundaria, los demás ya son independientes. Eulalia se dedica a la cría y engorda de borregos y vaquitas desde hace 5 años. “Cuando se es madre tenemos la obligación de darles lo mejor a nuestros hijos por eso mismo yo decidí iniciar mi propio negocio”. En un principio, Eulalia solicitó tres mil pesos a otra financiera, dinero que utilizó para comprar tres borreguitos, con el tiempo el número de animales ha ido en aumento. Ahora, está planeando comprar  dos vaquitas pequeños; normalmente los conserva durante todo un año para poder venderlos ya que han alcanzado un buen tamaño y peso. Doña Eulalia les dedica más de cinco horas al día, en las mañanas les da de comer en su propio corral, pero en las tardes debe sacarlos a pastar al campo. Ella debe esforsarse mucho para alcanzar su peso y tamaño ideal para venderlos a los mejores barbacoyeros Eulalia está muy contenta con sus animalitos aunque ahora habrá más trabajo con sus dos vaquitas; afortunadamente, cuando llegan a enfermar, ella misma los inyecta, su hijo que es veterinario fue quien le enseñó a hacerlo. La meta de Doña Eulalia es poder seguir aumentando el número de sus animales aunque su mayor anhelo es que su hijo menor termine una carrera profesional. “Yo no estudié y aunque quisiera encontrar un trabajo mejor, no puedo porque no tengo los conocimientos suficientes y no me gustaría que mi hijo pasara por lo mismo” comentó Doña Eulalia. En la comunidad donde viven los integrantes del grupo por lo regular los jóvenes solo terminan la secundaria, pero los padres siempre tratan de esforzarse y convencerlos de que continúen preparándose. 
*La fotografia fue tomada en un pequeño jardin del municipio*
texts.en:
Doña Eulalia is a very hardworking woman, age 44. She has been married to Señor Eulalio for 24 years, and together they have formed a family. They have four children, and all but one, who is studying in high school, are now independent. Eulalia has been raising and fattening lambs and cows for five years. She says, "As mothers we have an obligation to give the best to our children, which is why I decided to start my own business"

Initially, Eulalia requested three thousand pesos from another finance company and used the money to purchase three lambs. Over time, the number of animals has been growing, and now she is planning to purchase two calves. Normally, she keeps them for a year in order to sell them once they reach a good size and weight. Doña Eulalia devotes more than five hours a day to them. Mornings, she feeds them in her own corral, but she has to take them to the pasture to graze in the afternoons. She has to work very hard in order for them to reach the weight and size that are ideal for selling them to the best purveyors of barbecue.

Eulalia is very happy with her little animals, although now she will have more work to do with her two cows. Fortunately, when they get sick she can give them injections herself; her son, who is a veterinarian, taught her how to do it. Doña Eulalia's goal is to be able to continue increasing the number of her animals, although her greatest desire is that her youngest son may complete a professional degree. "I didn't study, and although I would like to find better work, I can't, because I don't have sufficient skills. I would not like the same thing to happen to my son", commented Doña Eulalia.

In the community where the group members live, young people usually only complete secondary school, but the parents always try hard to convince them to continue preparing themselves.

*The photograph was taken in a small garden in the municipality.

loans.use: to purchase two cows.

location.town: San Juan Cote, San Felipe del Progreso

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Jacob is a 35-year-old man who is hardworking, humble, and full of life. Despite all the obstacles that he has been presented with, he has never given up. He is a native of the village of Chebara in the Kapsowar area of Kenya where he lives with his family. His upbringing was challenging and he never went to college so that he could secure a formal job, but he did not surrender to that. He has been practicing farming for the past 10 years. Through farming, he has been able to take care of his family. His main source of income has been milk, eggs and crop farming, and through these ventures, he has supported his family because he is the only breadwinner. Jacob passionately loves farming. Jacob stated that the most enjoyable bit about farming is “it gives me personal fulfillment and feeds my family."

Although he has been making profits through farming, not everything has been easy for this humble and industrious man. He has been facing challenges transporting his produce from the farm to the market. That is why he is seeking a loan to buy a motorbike. The Kapsowar area is a rural town and roads are very poor, and transporting goods for Jacob has always been a “nightmare.” He has been suffering losses because goods reach the market when they are not fresh, hence fetching a low price. Vegetables and milk are very perishable and require timely delivery to the market. Through the loan, he will be able to achieve his dream. He plans to employ someone who will be helping him in farm work and in transporting the produce to the market, hence impacting the society positively through creation of employment.

Increased profits from the loan will allow him to repay the loan fully and be able to permanently change his living conditions and assure his aging parents of a secure future. His biggest dream is to be able to take care of his family by giving them a solid education because he believes that education is the key to success. You can be a part of this dream. Give a loan and make an impact on this man's life.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Ainagul

texts.ru: Айнагул, 58 лет,  замужем, дети взрослые и самостоятельные. У нее среднее образование, работает медицинской сестрой в больнице, также занимается полеводством и животноводством. Стартовав в 2004 году, благодаря упорному труду, на сегодняшний день у Айнагул имеется 1,45 ГА земельного надела, на котором она ежегодно выращивает фасоль для реализации. Также в хозяйстве есть корова, 10 овец, лошадь, куры и утки. Ежемесячный доход составляет до 24,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Айнагул обратилась в Банк "Бай-Тушум" за кредитом в сумме 55,000 сом (KGS) для сбора урожая и покупки теленка. Доходы от кредита Айнагул хочет вложить в дальнейшее развитие ее бизнеса и ремонт дома.
texts.en:
Ainagul is 58 and married. Her children are now adults and independent. She has a secondary education and works as a nurse in a hospital. In addition to her job, she has been involved in agriculture and animal husbandry since 2004. Thanks to her very hard work, she now owns 1.45 hectares of land on which she annually grows beans for resale. She also has one cow, ten sheep, one horse, as well as some chicken and ducks. She makes a monthly income of up to 24,000 som (KGS).

Eager to further grow her business, Ainagul has turned to Bai Tushum and requested a loan of 55,000 som (KGS) to buy a calf and pay for the cost of harvest. She wants to use the earnings from her loan to further expand her business and renovate her house.

loans.use: to buy one calf and pay for the cost of harvest.

loans.name: Madhabi

texts.en:
Forty-two-year-old Madhabi is a rural village woman who lives with her two sons and husband in a small village of Khagrabari in Coochbihar district. Besides the household chores, she involves herself in a “bidi” binding business. Bidi is one type of cigar and is generally popular as a low-cost smoking agent in the rural area.

Twenty-year-old Abhijit is the elder son of Madhabi. He is pursuing his bachelor’s degree (B.A) from Cooch Behar College. His younger brother also reads in grade 9. Madhabi’s husband Santosh is a farmer. In spite of their tireless work, they are only able to barely meet the household expenses of the family.

Whereas, Abhijit is trying his best to have a bachelor’s degree so that after graduation, he will be able to get a job and help his family and support his brother’s education. But, to achieve the degree, he needs good private tuition and adequate educational equipment, which seems like a burden to his parents now. Thus, Madhabi seeks a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner).

Madhabi will utilize the loan for purchasing books and other study materials, paying the exam fees and college fees, and enrolling Abhijit in good, private coaching classes, which will help him to pass the bachelor’s degree successfully.

Abhijit and Madhabi convey their heartiest thanks to Kiva and BJS.

loans.use: to purchase all education equipment and pay all fees for a bachelor's degree for her elder son.

loans.name: Erick

texts.en:
Erick is a rural smallholder crop farmer in Kericho, which is the largest tea-growing area in Kenya. Erick practices livestock and crop farming to make a living. The key lesson he has taken away from many years of being in crop farming is that high-quality farm inputs result in high quality and quantity of harvest.

Erick is seeking a loan to buy agricultural inputs. With the borrowed money, he plans to buy improved seeds and fertilizer to enhance his farm’s productivity. Your loan will increase Erick's chances for a successful harvest.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a kind-hearted man, but also very well-organized, industrious, and entrepreneurial. He is 28 years old, hard-working and energetic. He hails from the Kapsowar area of Kenya, an area that is blessed with good climatic conditions and favorable weather patterns that favor farming. Paul was raised in a humble family and he never got the opportunity to go to college because of a lack of tuition fees. As a result of this, he never got any formal employment and didn’t surrender to that. He started farming and, through farming, he has been able to take care of his family and also to take care of his parents.

Paul's sources of income are vegetables, milk, and egg-selling. These products are very perishable and require timely delivery to the market, but one problem that he faces is delivering to the market on time. The Kapsowar area has a poor road network and poor feeder roads that really hamper timely delivery of products to the market; that is why Paul is kindly seeking a loan to buy a motorbike. Using the motorbike, he will deliver products to the market on time and reap more profits because the products will still be fresh. Paul is very determined to succeed and, because he is very disciplined with finances, he expects that, through accumulated profits, he will be able to provide a secure future for himself and also for his parents. Paul's dream is to go back to school and he hopes that, through your loan, you will help him realize his dream.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to deliver his farm products to market.

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
At 39 years of age, Tabitha is a charismatic, active, and helpful woman. Being a smallholder farmer has been her main reason to tirelessly struggle day by day, looking for alternatives to earn her living and to support her family. Approximately 10 years ago, she started farming. Tabitha is hardworking and determined to make it in the world of farming. The land she owns is big enough to support more than just dairy animals. She is planning to make use of the available space to start growing food crops.

Starting a horticultural farm is very costly, especially for small-holder rural farmers. Besides securing land space, a farmer needs to invest in intensive labour, farm tools, and farm inputs. The farmer will also have to construct a store/granary for her produce. Tabitha is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to buy seeds and venture into horticulture. With your loan investment into her business, Tabitha will have an alternative source of income besides dairy in the near future. This will not only make her family better off but also open new possibilities for her to diversify further in future.

loans.use: to buy seeds and venture into horticulture farming.

loans.name: Vista Hermosa Group

texts.es:
El grupo "Vista Hermosa" se encuentra en una comunidad muy pequeña del Estado de México es un lugar pequeño, pero con personas muy alegres pero sobretodo trabajadoras, ellas aun conservan su lengua materna, algunas fiestas aptronales que duran aproximadamente tres o cuatro días son días de mucha celebración.
 Lucila, es una mujer muy trabajadora y entusiasta de 32 años de edad, esta casada desde hace mucho tiempo con Arnulfo quien trabaja en la construcción de casas y son padres de 4 niños tres de ellos se encuentran estudiando su educación primaria. Anteriormente, la familia vivía en la capital del país, pero vivir en la ciudad significaba muchos gastos y el sueldo de su esposo era el mínimo lo cual no era suficiente para solventar todos los gastos de hogar. Fue entonces que decidió iniciar a vender antojitos mexicanos como chicharrones preparados, patitas de pollo, elotes, esquites, entre otros. El negocio resultó productivo porque a los clientes les gustaba el sazón de Lucila y así permaneció durante dos años. Todas las tardes, afuera de la casa donde rentaba colocaba una mesita para vender, pero desafortunadamente otras señoras comenzaron negocios muy similares y el de Lucila fue decayendo poco a poco y lo tuvo que abandonar. Un día, su esposo también tuvo un mal momento y se quedó sin empleo, fue cuando se vieron obligados a regresar a su comunidad donde llevan viviendo ya 10 años. Hace 7 años, Lucila decidió iniciar con la venta de dulces dulces frente a una escuela primaria, pero le gustaría retomar la venta de sus antojitos mexicanos porque sabe que las ganancias son mayores. Con la venta de una paleta ella gana sólo un peso, pero con un platillo, gana alrededor de 10. Por el momento Lucila no cuenta con la inversión para iniciar el negocio de comida, pero trabajará para lograrlo, así que necesita un préstamo que invertirá en dulces, con su ingreso apoyará a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y seguirá ahorrando. Sin embargo, el mayor sueño de Lucila es mejorar su vivienda, hasta ahora el piso es de tierra y las ventanas las adecuaron para cubrirse del frío, pero ella quiere un mejor hogar para su familia.
Los integrantes del grupo son Gabriel quien invertirá en cerdos y venta de autos, Cristina en reaccionaria, Carmen en guajolotes, Angel en tienda de abarrotes.
*La fotografia fue tomada junto a uno de los autos que esta vendiendo Don Gabriel, Lucia es quien tiene cargando el bebe y Gabriel es quien tiene el sombrero*
texts.en:
The group “Vista Hermosa” can be found in a very small community in the State of Mexico. It’s small with very cheerful, but above all hardworking, people. They still preserve their mother tongue and have patronage festivals that last approximately three or four days; they’re days with a lot of celebrating.

Lucila is a very enthusiastic and hardworking 32 year old woman. She has been married for a long time to Arnulfo who builds homes, and they are parents to four children. Three of them are studying in primary school. Previously, the family lived in the capital of the country, but living in the city meant a lot of expenses; her husband’s minimum wage salary was not sufficient to pay all of the household expenses. It was then she decided to start selling Mexican snacks like prepared chicharrones, chicken feet, corn on the cob, and esquite (fried and seasoned corn) among other things.

The business was profitable because customers liked Lucila’s seasoning, and it remained liked that for two years. Every afternoon outside of the house she rented, she placed a small table to sell. But unfortunately, other ladies began businesses very similar to Lucila’s. Lucila’s business declined little by little, and she had to give it up. One day, her husband had a rough time too and was left without a job. That was when they were forced to return to their community where they have been living for ten years.

Seven years ago, Lucila decided to start selling sweets in front of a primary school, but she would like to resume selling Mexican snacks because she knows the profits are higher. By selling one popsicle she only earns one peso, but with a small plate of food she earns around 10. At the moment, Lucila does not have the money to start a food business, but she will work to achieve it. That’s why she needs a loan to invest in sweets. Her income will support her husband with the household expenses, and she will continue to save. However, Lucila’s biggest dream is to improve her home. Up until now, it has a dirt floor and the windows are enough to keep out the cold, but she wants a better home for her family.

The members of the group are Gabriel (who will invest in pigs and car sales), Cristina (who will invest in a repair shop), Carmen (who will invest in turkeys), and Angel (who will invest in a grocery store).

*The photo was taken together with one of the cars Gabriel is selling. Lucila is the one carrying the baby, and Gabriel is the one wearing the sombrero*

loans.use: to buy sweets.

location.town: San Ramón, San Jose del Rincon

loans.name: Dickson

texts.en:
At 42 years old, Dickson has gone through various circumstances and difficulties in his life. Just to mention one of them, he lacks funds to improve his farming. Dickson is a very industrious, honest and hardworking man from the Chuka area of Kenya, near the famous Mount Kenya. Dickson has been farming for the past 10 years. Through these years, he has gained a lot of experience and is considered among the best farmers in his village. His primary sources of income have been milk, eggs, crops, and some small business ventures that help him make ends meet. Dickson is very passionate about farming and loves cultivating his farm. That is why, every day, he wakes up very early to go to his farm to plough.

Although he makes profits from farming, he is not comfortable and has always wanted to increase his income by selling cereals. That is why he is seeking this loan to buy cereal. Kenya's Chuka area, one of the county's populated regions, has a high demand for cereal. This means that Dickson could increase his profits and satisfy the demand that is there.

Accessing funds has been a challenge for Dickson, but he now feels relieved because Juhudi Kilimo is partnering with Kiva lenders to help aspiring male farmers like him turn their farming dreams into reality through training and loan financing. Dickson believes that this loan will be a lot of help, and that he will be able to satisfy the demand for cereal. He also believes that the extra income he earns will enable a permanent change in his life and increase his business. Increased profits will allow Dickson to repay this loan and secure the future of his school-going children.

loans.use: to buy cereal

loans.name: Wilfred

texts.en:
Wilfred is a smallholder farmer based in Kiera village in Chuka Kenya. He owns a 0.5-acre piece of land that he uses to grow maize and keep dairy animals. He has also planted 100 trees on it for their aesthetic appearance and for environmental health. Not only does the land provide him with capital for his business, but also a home for his family. He is blessed to have four children with a wife to whom he has stayed married for more than 20 years.

Wilfred is seeking a loan to purchase cereals. The cereals he is seeking serve to replenish stock for his food and his business. The demand for cereals in the market, only a few kilometers from Wilfred's home, is up. Farmers in the area are rushing to grow more cereal crops. By placing himself in a position of supplying cereal seeds and still being a cereal farmer, he gets to enjoy profits from selling inputs and crop harvests. He is very pragmatic and considers himself more hardworking than others. Your loan will directly elevate Wilfred’s livelihood. He strives to give his children a better life than the tough upbringing he had while growing up.

loans.use: to buy cereals.

loans.name: Gitithia Center Small Traders Self Help Group

texts.en:
The man raising his hand in the photo is James. He is 62 years old, married, and living with his wife and his five children. James joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2014 so as to benefit from the trainings, especially enterprise development.

He is a vegetable farmer, growing potatoes and cabbage. In addition, he also washes and irons clothes, especially men’s coats. He is borrowing a loan to buy secondhand clothes to sell in his dry cleaning shop so as to increase his income level. With increased income, he will be able to buy a cow, hence expanding his farming.

James is grateful to Kiva and their lenders. He promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy secondhand clothes for resale. He will use the increased income to buy a cow, hence expanding his farming.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine, shown in the photo,  is 41 years old and has two children. She is married and lives with her family. She farms maize and beans. She is grateful to Hand in Hand Eastern Africa enterprise management training which equipped her with knowledge. She is borrowing from Kiva to buy fertilizer and seeds that will boost her farm output. This will enable her to improve her family's living standards. She intends to use part of the profit to provide food to the family and pay school fees. Catherine is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds that will boost her farm output. This will enable her to improve her family's living standards.

loans.name: Claudia Liliana

texts.es:
Durante el recorrido hacia la novia del sol se pueden apreciar los plantíos de caña de azúcar, potreros  puesto que la zona es una de las más ricas en la producción de caña de azúcar, por lo que la mayoría de los pobladores ha entregado su vida al campo.

Doña Claudia es una mujer emprendedora tiene 45 años de edad, procreo 5 hijos con su esposo el señor Jacinto y adoptaron a uno más hace 10 años, el firme propósito de apoyar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa, la educación de sus hijos y sus gastos personales iniciando con la venta de antojitos de lunes a domingo de 7: 00 pm a 12:00 am, comenta que cuando inicio preparaba la comida en una pequeña parrilla, una mesa pequeña, un sartén amplio y dos tablitas donde palmeaba la maza para las picaditas y empanadas, sus clientes comían de pie, todo eso ha cambiado  con los préstamos que Visión F México le ha otorgado.

Cada préstamo le ha permitido crecer de manera continua, las ganancias le han permitido comprar una parrilla de 4 quemadores, un refrigerador, tres mesas con sillas, un comal, manteles, servilleteros, salseros  ofreciendo un servicio de calidad a cada uno de sus clientes.

En esta ocasión el préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de verduras, crema, queso, aceite, huevos, carne, 1 licuadora, 1 batidora, 1 tanque de gas y pondrá maya alrededor de su casa.

Para doña Claudia contar con el apoyo de sus hijos es la mejor motivación que puede recibir, recientemente  ella y sus dos hijos pequeños  iniciaron con la cría de gallinas de rancho, construyendo un pequeño corral en casa.

“Gracias a cada una de las personas que ha hecho posible  el préstamo me haya sido otorgado pues con el mi actividad crecerá cada vez más, dios los bendiga hoy y siempre” son las palabras de agradecimiento de doña Claudia.

*Este es el pequeño rincón donde doña Claudia satisface el apetito de sus clientes.
texts.en:
On the way to La Novia del Sol one can appreciate the sugar cane plantations. These pastures were put there because the area is one of the richest in sugar cane production. This is why most of the population dedicates their lives to the fields. 

Doña Claudia is an entrepreneurial woman. She is 45 years old, and has had five children with her husband Jacinto and adopted one more child ten years ago. With the purpose of helping her husband with household expenses, her children’s education and her personal expenses, she sells snacks Monday through Sunday from 7:00 pm to 12:00 am. She says that when she first started she prepared the food with a small grill, a small table, a large pan and two small cutting boards where she kneaded the dough for the picaditas and empanadas [traditional snacks]. Her customers ate standing up.

All this has changed with the loans Visión F México has given her. Every loan has allowed her to grow continuously, and her earnings have allowed her to buy a grill with 4 burners, a refrigerator, three tables with chairs, a griddle, tablecloths, napkin holders and salt shakers, offering quality service to each of her customers. She will invest this loan in buying vegetables, cream, cheese, oil, eggs, meat, a blender, a beater, and a tank of gas, and a wire fence for her house. 

For Claudia, counting on her children’s support is the best motivation she could receive. Recently she and her two young children began to raise farm chickens, building a small coral at home. 

“Thanks to all the people who have made this loan I have been given possible. My activities will grow more every time, God bless you today and always.” These are the words of thanks from Doña Claudia. 

*This is the small corner where Claudia satisfies her customers’ appetites.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, cream, cheese, oil, eggs, meat, a blender, a beater, and a tank of gas, and a wire fence for her house.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Charles. He is forty-one-years-old, married and the father of six children. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2014. He farms vegetables in a green house as his main business while also running a kiosk. He has benefited much from Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) training on enterprise and financial management-it has enabled him to manage his business well. He is borrowing from Kiva to purchase more quality inputs such as seeds and to add stock to the kiosk to increase his income. Doing this will enable him to cater to his family's needs with food, medicine and by paying his children's school fees.
He is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to pay promptly.

loans.use: to purchase more quality inputs such as seeds and to add stock to his kiosk to increase his income.

loans.name: Ayangleima Group

texts.en:
Pakpi is a 27 year old living in Bishnupur District, Manipur (India). She has formed a group called Ayangleima. The group has five members and together they need a loan of RS 50,000 for their respective businesses. All the women are micro-entrepreneurs.

Pakpi is the leader of this group and she lives with her husband and eight-year-old son. Her husband works as a daily wage worker and she weaves to meet their daily needs. Currently her household income is RS 5000 which can increase up to RS 7,500 with the help of a loan that she would utilise for buying raw materials like thread, dye for making mekhalas, towels, saris, loin wrappers, and bed sheets. She wants to secure the future of her child and works really hard to save as much as she can.

The other members of the group also want to utilise the loan for purchasing additional raw materials to increase their productivity, which will help them save some amount for the proper education of their children. This group of women is thankful to you for your loan.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials like yarn for her weaving business making towels, mekhalas, saris, bed sheets, etc.

loans.name: Chinichampra Group

texts.en:
Bimola is a 36-year-old married woman, hailing from the Bishnupur district of Manipur state in the Eastern part of India. She is a mother of one and lives with her family of three. She is the group leader and is engaged in a weaving business of her own.

She seeks a loan to expand her weaving business by purchasing more raw material. She is looking to increase her production, which will eventually help her sell more final products like towels, saris, bed sheets, etc. and help her to earn a higher income. The other members of the group are also engaged in various income-generation activities like fish selling, vegetable selling and weaving. All the members will use the loan to buy more stock and raw materials to expand their respective businesses. Hence they decided to form a group and apply for a loan. They are well aware of the group rules and agreed to abide by them. They are thankful to the lenders for their support.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to expand her weaving business and sell towels, saris, loin wrappers, bed sheets, etc

loans.name: Bidii B Women Group

texts.en: The woman in the photo is Sharon. She is a member of Bidii B Women Group. She is 30 years old and married with three children. She is a maize farmer and runs a retail kiosk that sells foodstuffs and offers money transfer services. Having undergone Hand in Hand Eastern Africa training on enterprise management and enterprise development, she learned how to draw her budget and source for a good business idea. She is borrowing a loan from Kiva, which she intends to use in buying additional stock which includes sugar, tea leaves and flour. This will help to improve her sales and thus earn more income that will enable her to provide food to her family. She is very grateful to Kiva and Hand in Hand Eastern Africa for the support and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy stock of foodstuffs that will help to improve her sales and thus earn more income that will enable her to provide food to her family.

loans.name: 1Ero De Noviembre Group

texts.es:
La siembre de caña de azúcar y el cultivo alternativo son la máxima fuente de empleo en la zona tan es así que a tan solo dos kilómetros de la comunidad se encuentra uno de los ingenios (fabrica) que más actividad tienen durante la zafra, en una de las comunidades se ha formado un grupo el cual lleva por nombre 1ero de noviembre nombre que decidieron por la calle donde se reúnen.

el grupo esta integrado por:
Rubicela – Abarrotes, Cosméticos Y Medicina Naturista 
Jorge –Cultivo De Caña De Azúcar 
Maria –Zapatos 
Ciria, Jesus – Perfumes 
Juan,  Miguel – Servicio De Albañil 
Lilian – Antojitos Y Postres 
Mercedes –Comida 
Lidia –Tamales Y Cosméticos 

Doña rubicela  tiene 54 años de edad, estudio la primaria, en la comunidad le conocen como “chela” o “rubí” desde hace 9 años que enviudo ha sido padre y madre de sus 5 hijos de los cuales solo  una adolescente depende económicamente de ella,  con el firme propósito de que los ingresos en casa fuesen mayores y debido a la distancia de las tiendas de abarrotes inicio hace 11 años con una pequeña tienda, comenta que cuando inicio compraba 5 litros de aceite, 10 kilos de frijol, arroz, 5 leches, 10pasta para sopa , nortomate y noszuiza, pues tenía miedo a no vender la mercancía, al pasar los meses la pequeña tienda logro su estabilidad e incremento la mercancía ofertada tan es así que hoy en día vende; arroz, frijol, azúcar, aceite, minsa, harina, sopa, atún, mayonesa, chiles enlatados, galletas, pan , huevos, queso, tortillas  y refresco.
Además de vender abarrotes hace 5 años inicio con la venta de cosméticos por catálogo y medicina naturista incrementando sus ingresos, “no es necesario salir a mostrar los catálogos, mis clientas vienen a la casa y se los agradezco pues así no descuido mi tiendita”

Las ganancias obtenidas le han permitido ofrecer estudio a sus hijos, adquirir una estufa nueva, una cama, un refrigerador  y satisfacer sus necesidades personales, en esta ocasión el préstamo empleara en la compra de  azúcar, sopa, arroz, aceite, refrescos y detergente para continuar con el servicio en su pequeña tienda a partir de las 7: 00 am hasta las 8:00 pm y en ocasiones un poco más tarde.

“Gracias a cada una de las personas que hacen posible podamos cumplir nuestros sueños al otorgarnos un préstamo para invertirlo en nuestra actividad o iniciar una nueva, a mí me han favorecido lo prestamos que ese me han otorgado” son las palabras de doña “Chela”

Ampliar la infraestructura donde se encuentra su tienda es el reto de doña chela durante este  ciclo pues comenta que el espacio donde esta es un poco pequeño y pretende exhibir la medicina naturista en la tienda.

*la fotografía fue tomada en la parte delantera de la pequeña tienda de doña Chela quien viste blusa blanca y falda a cuadros.
texts.en:
Raising sugar cane and alternative crops are the greatest source of employment in this zone, so much so that only two kilometers from the community is one of the factories that has the most activity during the sugar harvest. In one of the communities, a group has been formed that carries the name "First of November," a name that they decided on because of the street where they meet.

The group consists of: Rubicela, who sells groceries, cosmetics, and natural medicines; Jorge, who raises sugar cane; Maria, who sells shoes; Ciria and Jesús, who sell perfumes; Juan and Miguel, who provide masonry services; Lilian, who sells snacks and deserts; Mercedes, who sells food; and Lidia, who sells tamales and cosmetics.

Doña Rubicela is 54 years old. She attended primary school. In the community she is known as "Chela" or "Rubi." In the nine years since she was widowed, she has been father and mother to her five children, of whom only one adolescent depends on her economically. With the firm resolve that  the household income be greater, and due to the distance of the grocery stores, she began 11 years ago with a little store. She comments that when she started out, she bought 5 liters of oil, 10 kilos of beans and rice, 5 of milk, and 10 of pasta for soup, Knorr tomato and Knorr Swiss, since she was afraid of not selling the merchandise. As the months passed, the little store achieved stability and she increased the merchandise offered, so much so that today she sells rice, beans, sugar, oil, Minsa corn flour, flour, soup, tuna, mayonnaise, canned chiles, crackers, bread, eggs, cheese, tortillas, and soft drinks. 

In addition to selling groceries, five years ago she began the sale of cosmetics by catalog and natural medicines, increasing her income. "It is not necessary to go out and show the catalogs. My customers come to the house, and I am grateful to them since this way I don't have to neglect my little store."

The earnings obtained have allowed her to offer an education to her children, to acquire a new stove, a bed, and a refrigerator, and to satisfy her personal necessities. At this time she will use the loan for the purchase of sugar, soup, rice, oil, soft drinks, and detergents in order to continue with service in her little store from 7:00 am to 8:00 pm, and sometimes a little later.

"Thanks to each one of the people who make it possible for us to achieve our dreams when we are granted a loan to invest in our business or begin a new one. The loans that have been granted to me have given me an advantage," are the words of Doña Chela.

Expanding the infrastructure where her store is located is Doña Chela's challenge during this loan cycle, since she comments that the space where it is is a little small, and she hopes to display natural medicines in the store.

The photograph was taken in the back part of Doña Chela's little store. She is the one wearing a white blouse and a checked skirt.

loans.use: to buy sugar, soup, rice, oil, soft drinks, and detergent for her store

loans.name: Carlito

texts.en: Carlito is a married man from Talibon, Bohol. He owned a barn where he housed his hogs. He started raising hogs five months ago. He only earned PHP 1,500 per month. With two children to support, he is struggling in his business. He is asking for a loan to buy more piglets to raise and stock of feed to fatten them. Carlito knows how important it is to provide them the necessary feed so they grow fast and healthy. His income will go toward his children’s education, healthy meals, savings and reinvestment in the same business.

loans.use: to buy piglets and feed

loans.name: Ezekiel

texts.en:
Ezekiel 35 years old is married and supports two children.

He is a small-scale farmer. He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase certified fertilizers, herbicides and pesticides to spray his crops for quality production.

He plans to use the gained profits to repay his loan and buy a dairy cow to supplement his farming activity.

He hopes to lease more land for large-scale farming.

loans.use: to purchase certified fertilizers, herbicides and pesticides to spray his crops for quality production.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith is 42 years old. She is married and has four children. She runs a retail shop and a mobile phone money transfer business. Besides these, she also has a beauty salon and the business has been profitable. She will use the loan to buy more stock of retail goods such as flour, sugar and rice to sell and also to buy equipment for her beauty salon. She will use the profits from her expanded business to pay school fees for her children and buy more retail goods to sell. Her hopes and dreams for the future are to expand her business and become a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: to buy more stock of retail goods such as flour, sugar and rice to sell and also to buy equipment for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy organic fertilizers

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: The lady  in the photo is Jane. She is 33 years old, married and a mother of four. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2012. She does maize and bean farming as her main business. She has benefited a lot from Hand in Hand Eastern Africa training on enterprise and financial management. This has helped her in budgeting and record keeping. She is borrowing from Kiva to buy quality fertilizer so that she can increase her output . This will assist her to cater for the family needs and in paying the school fee. She is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to pay promptly.

loans.use: to buy quality fertilizer so that she can increase her output and pay school fees.

loans.name: Mbogoini Agriculture Farmers Group

texts.en: The person raising his hand in the photo is Samuel, 68 years old, married with five dependents. He is a member of Mbogoini Agriculture Farmers self help group. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in 2012 and has been trained on enterprise and financial management. His main economic activity is maize, bean and vegetable farming and he is borrowing from Kiva to buy pesticides and fertilizer. This will increase the yield and therefore increase his income too. This will improve his living standards and enable him to afford better housing and food for his dependents. He is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to pay his loan on time.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and therefore increases farm output and results in a better income for his dependents' housing and food.

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en: Joshua is a married man with five children. He describes himself as committed. He operates a retail business where he sells juices, rice, bread, flour, sugar and other items. He has been involved in this business for 12 years. His primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be high transportation costs. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of rice, sugar, bread, flour, salt and other items. His business goal is to have a wholesale business within five years. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of rice, sugar, bread, flour, salt and other items.

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is 38 years old, married and supports four children. He is in the motorcycle transport business and it has been profitable. He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase spare parts to repair, service and maintain his motorcycle to able to serve his customers satisfactorily. He plans to use the gained profits to repay his loan and educate his children. He hopes to buy a dairy cow to meet his family's demands of milk and also improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts to repair, service and maintain his motorcycle to able to serve his customers satisfactorily.

loans.name: Molly

texts.en: Molly is a married woman with four children. She describes herself as committed. She operates a retail business where she sells tomatoes and onions. She has been involved in this business for 17 years. Her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be high transportation costs. She will use the KES 60,000 loan to buy more stock of tomatoes and onions. Her business goal is to have a wholesale business within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will be successful. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tomatoes and onions.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is 66 years old, married and a mother of four children. She farms maize to earn an income. In 2011 she joined Kiva's field partner Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) and successfully underwent enterprise development and financial management training.


Anna has applied for a 25,000 KES loan to buy pesticides and fertilizer for her farm so she realize a better yield and more income. This will enable her to provide better clothing and food for her family. The loan will also pay school fees for her granddaughter who is under her care and currently in school.

loans.use: to buy pesticides and fertilizer for her maize farm

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a married woman who is 33-years-old and the mother of 3 children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2014 to benefit from the training offered; specifically enterprise development.
She practices mixed farming focusing on vegetables (cabbages, kale and potatoes) as well as dairy farming. She also sells second hand clothes. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy a calf to expand her dairy farming. This will increase milk production in the future and enable her to earn more income to support her children's education.

Susan is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the financial support. She promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy a calf to increase milk production and income to support her children's education.

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en: Joshua is a married man. He has five children. He describes himself as committed. He operates a brick-making business. He has been involved in this business for 14 years. His primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be rain which damages bricks. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy firewood and soil for making bricks. He hopes that in the future, he will prosper. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy firewood and soil for making bricks.

loans.name: Centre Development Project Group

texts.en:
The person raising his hand is Pharis; he is married and a father of six children. He joined Hand in HandEastern Africa (HiH EA) in 2012 and has gone through training on enterprise development and financial management. He has benefited a lot and was able to start a green grocer business.
His enterprise consists of maize, bananas, cabbages and rosemary plants. He is borrowing from Kiva to buy a calf and start dairy farming to diversify his business. This will enable him to earn more income which will help him provide better food for his family and to pay school fees for his children.
He is grateful to Kiva and its lenders and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy a calf to diversify his income to pay school fees.

loans.name: Jitahidi Self Help Group

texts.en: The person raising her hand in the photo is Peris, a member of Jitahidi Self Help Group in Nakuru. She is 26 years old, married and blessed with one child. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in 2013. Peris does maize, bean and potato farming on her small farm. She is grateful for HiH EA enterprise training that has enabled her to manage the enterprise well. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to purchase farm inputs such as seeds that will help increase yields, resulting in better income to enable her to support basic family needs such as education, Medicare and clothing. She is happy with Kiva and their lenders for their intervention and she promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as seeds that will help increase yields, resulting in a better income to enable her to support basic family needs such as education, Medicare and clothing.

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: Nicholas is a married man with one child. He describes himself as honest. He operates a retail business where he sells soft drinks, bread, flour, sugar and other items. He has been involved in this business for five years. His primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, bread, flour, salt and other items. His business goal is to own a supermarket within five years. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, bread, flour, salt and other items.

loans.name: Lari Pioneer Vegetable Processors (C.b.o) Group

texts.en:
The man raising his hand is called James. He is 49 years old, married and living with his wife and his four children. He joined Hand in Hand in the year 2013 so as to benefit from the trainings especially enterprise development.

James practices farming of potatoes and kale. He also buys and sells vegetables in the nearest market. He has applied for a Kiva loan to buy fertilizer and certified vegetable seeds so as to improve the quality and increase vegetable production. This, he hopes, will enable him to earn more income to meet his family's expenses e.g. food and clothing.

He is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the financial support. He promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and certified vegetable seeds to improve quality and increase production for more income to meet family expenses e.g. food and clothing.

loans.name: Gituamba Abc Women Group

texts.en:
The lady raising her hand in the photo is Margaret. She is 29 years old, married, and blessed with two children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa so as to benefit from the trainings, especially enterprise development.

She keeps sheep and also buys and sells vegetables. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy more vegetables, hence add stock and consequently satisfy and retain her customers. This will increase her income to enable her pay for her family's basic needs such as food and clothing.

Margaret is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the financial support. She promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables and hence have more income for food and clothing.

loans.name: Rasoltaabasida De Tanghin Group

texts.fr:
Mr DAHAMANE est responsable du groupe RASOLTAABASIDA DE TANGHIN. Il est marié et père de 07 enfants. Le plus âgé a 12 ans et le moins âgé a 08 mois. 02 enfants vont à l’école et il a 10 personnes en charge.
Mr est éleveur depuis 39 ans.Il pratique aussi l'agriculture. Il s’approvisionne dans les marchés environnants.
Avec l’argent octroyé, il compte acheter 03 moutons et 10 poules.
Il veut utiliser les bénéfices du prêt pour réinvestir dans son activité. Il ambitionne devenir un grand éleveur.
texts.en: Mr. DAHAMANE is the head of the RASOLTAABASIDA DE TANGHIN group. He is a married father of seven, the eldest of whom is 12 and the youngest of whom is 8 months. Two of his children attend school, and he is responsible for ten people. Mr. DAHAMANE has been a breeder for 39 years. He also farms. He stocks up in the nearby markets. With the granted loan, he plans to buy three sheep and ten hens. He wants to use his earnings to reinvest in his business. He has the ambition of becoming a large breeder.

loans.use: to buy three sheep and ten hens.

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel is 26-years-old, married and has one child. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2015 to benefit from the training-specifically enterprise development.

Joel practices farming: mostly vegetables such as cabbages, kales, carrots and potatoes. He also buys and sells milk. He is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy more milk to sell so he can meet his customers demand and also increase his profit. He hopes that this will enable him meet his family's basic expenses e.g. food and clothing.

He is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: to buy more milk for resale therefore earning more income to meet his family's basic needs.

loans.name: Triphosah's Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in this photo is Jane. She is 67, married and a mother of five children. She is a member of the Riandegwa Maendeleo Women group and is also its leader. In 2014 she joined Kiva's field partner Hand in Hand Eastern Africa and successfully underwent enterprise development and financial management training.


Jane practices mixed farming, growing maize, beans, avocadoes and cassava. She has applied for a 30,000 KES loan to be apportioned among her group members.
