She will use her share to buy fertilizer for her farm. Her farm will be more productive, and she will use the additional income to care for her family. She will also pay school fees for her grandson.


Jane is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to pay back her loan on time.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farm.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
Jacinta is 55 years old, married and a mother of four children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2014 so as to benefit from the trainings, especially enterprise development.

She practices mixed farming. She also buys and sells animal skins to supplement her income. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy more skins for resale. With increased stock and income, she will be able to pay her for her children's school fees with ease.

Jacinta is grateful to Kiva and her lenders for the financial support. She promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy more animal skins for resale, hence increasing her stock and her income to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Kamuti Uwezo Women Group

texts.en:
The member that is raising her hand in the photo is called Tabitha. She is 54 years old, married and has a family of six children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in 2015 to be trained and to be taken through loan management skills and the process of starting small enterprises that can earn her a living. She does cereal and dairy farming as her main business.

The purpose of applying for this Kiva loan is to buy seeds and fertilizer. The loan will help her to increase her farming production and thereby improve her living standards by enabling her to access better healthcare services. Tabitha is very grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the loan as it will help her to expand her farming and be in a position to provide for her personal and family needs well.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer to boost production to enable her to get better healthcare and buy basic necessities such as food and clothing.

loans.name: Macharia

texts.en:
Macharia is 60 years old, married and blessed with four children. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2015 so as to benefit from the training, especially enterprise development.

He practices mixed farming; potatoes, snow peas and keeps dairy cows. He is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy animal feeds and manure which will increase his farming production, resulting in increased income. He believes that this will enable him to pay for the construction expenses for a modern cow shed.

He is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: to buy animal feeds and manure, hence increasing farming production and increasing his income, which will enable him to pay for construction expenses for a modern cow shed.

loans.name: Carmela

texts.en:
Carmela lives in Talibon, Bohol. She is a 63-year-old married woman and a mother of six grown-up children. For more than 10 years , Carmela has operated a sari-sari (general) store in her place to earn a living. She sells various goods like canned food, shampoo, coffee, conditioner, bath soap, detergent, noodles, salt and vinegar. She also makes dresses for other people and raises hogs for additional income.

She is asking for a loan to buy toothpaste, canned goods, noodles, soap, toiletries and detergents, bread and biscuits, cooking oil, condiments, powdered fruit juice, candy, snacks, cloth and feed. This will help her improve her stock, allowing her to cater to more buyers in her store. Carmela dreams of living in comfort in the future.

loans.use: to buy toothpaste, canned goods, noodles, soap, toiletries and detergents, bread and biscuits, cooking oil, condiments, powdered fruit juice, candy, snacks, cloth and feed

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is 47 years old. He is married and has three children. He has a lorry transportation business and the business has been profitable. He serves customers in other towns as well. He has been in the business for 10 years. He will use the loan to service his lorry so it can be in  good condition. He hopes this will enable him to serve more customers and make more income. He will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for his children and provide food for the family. His hopes and dreams for the future are to expand his transportation business by buying more transportation vehicles, making more income and being able to support his family.

loans.use: to service his lorry so it can be in good condition. He hopes this will enable him to serve more customers and make more income.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en: Carmelita is married to a fisherman. They have two children together, ages 18 and 22. She engages in fishing in order to help her husband. She sells his catch and helps to prepare his fishing tools. She has been in this fishing business for 22 years. Due to lack of capital to finance her livelihood, Carmelita requested a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy materials like fishing nets and payment for boat repair. In the future, Carmelita hopes to have another fishing boat . She also plans to start a sari-sari store business while sending her child to school.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets and pay for boat repair

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase spare parts to repair, service and maintain his motorcycle to able to serve his customers satisfactorily.

loans.name: Muranga Upendo Women Group

texts.en:
The lady raising her hand in the photo is Susan, a member of Muranga Upendo Women Group. She is 34 years old, married and a mother of four children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in October 2014.

Susan does maize, bean and poultry farming. Having gone through enterprise training provided by Hand in Hand Eastern Africa, she is now able to manage her farming business from mainly subsistence to commercial. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to add more chicks to her poultry enterprise as well as to purchase chicken feeds. She hopes to obtain more income through the sale of chicken meat and eggs. This will enable her to support her children’s education, medical care and other family needs.

She is happy with Kiva and their lenders for the financial support. She promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy chicks and chicken feed that will boost farm output and enable her to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Munyaka Progressive Self Help Group

texts.en: The gentleman raising his hand in the photo is David. He is 54 years old, married and blessed with five children. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2013 so as to benefit from the training, especially enterprise development.  He practices mixed farming and also keeps cattle. He is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy certified seeds and manure, which will boost farming production. This will give him more income to provide better food and clothing to his family. He is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the financial support.  He promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy certified seeds and manure. This will boost farming production giving him more income to provide better food and clothing to his family.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is 39 years old. She lives in Talibon, Bohol. She is married with 7 children ages 3 to 17. Cecilia does her best to earn a living in order to provide support for the needs of the family. She operates a sari-sari store and also cooks food to sell. Her business provides her the income that she needs.

Cecilia wants to expand her business to generate more income but she needs funds to do this. She is requesting a loan to buy soft drinks, noodles, shampoo, condiments and toiletries.

Cecilia wants to earn more so that she will have the financial capacity to send her children to school for learning. She believes that education is important for a bright future.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, noodles, shampoo, condiments and toiletries

loans.name: Alfa Group

texts.es:
El bulevar de la ciudad se engalana con los vestigios arqueológicos que enmarcan la cultura mazateca algunos son, las caritas sonrientes, el monumento a la mujer y el monumento a la bandera de igual manera la gran locomotora de vapor llamada la prieta linda la cual fue la primera en transitar por las vías donde hoy en día corre la bestia.

En una de las comunidades de la pequeña ciudad se ha consolidado un grupo llamado Alfa pues para las integrantes del grupo significa Dios quien les ayuda con sus actividades día con día, actualmente el grupo consta de 10 integrantes.

Nancy –Cosméticos 
Rosalía –Ropa Y Carpintería 
Severa –Postres 
Elsa – Cosméticos Y Ropa 
Maresa, Julia –Ropa Interior Por Catálogo
Margarita – Comida Y Jugos 
Dora –Ropa 
Virginia – Cría De Cerdos 
Abigail – Venta De Dulces Y Pan 

Doña Rosalía tiene 42 años de edad, todos le conocen como “Chalia” está casada con el señor Miguel Ángel quien se desempeña como carpintero, son padres de 2 hijos mayores de edad, desde hace 5 años que se quedaron solos en casa doña Chalia se ha dedicado ayudar a su esposo en la carpintería a lijar, barnizar y a medir los muebles que elaboran, de igual manera inicio con la venta de ropa de manera ambulante, por las tardes después de apoyar a su esposo en la carpintería y cuando el sol ha cesado un poco sale a recorrer las calles para llegar a casa de cada uno de sus clientes para mostrarles la ropa.

Con las ganancias obtenidas de la carpintería han logrado comprar un lote donde han instalado la carpintería de manera fija y no andan pagando renta de tal manera que las ganancias son mayores, las ganancias obtenidas de la ropa las invierte en la compra de pantalones, blusas, camisas con el fin de ofrecer un extenso surtido a sus clientes, y en conjunto las ganancias les han servido para remodelar su casa “ así como construimos la carpintería construiremos un pequeño local al lado de la carpintería  para exhibir la ropa y no descuidar las actividades”

En esta ocasión el préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de pantalones, blusas, camisas, brochas y barniz para que la inversión sea en ambas actividades.

“Gracias por los préstamos otorgados, con cada uno de ellos la actividad de cada uno de nosotros se ha fortalecido y con las ganancias brindamos mejor calidad de vida a nuestra familia”

*la fotografía fue tomada en casa de Maresa, doña Chalia es quien viste blusa color rosa y capri negro.
texts.en:
The boulevard of the city is adorned with the archaeological vestiges that belong to the Mazatec culture. Some of these are the smiling little faces, the monument to women, and the monument to the flag. Likewise, there is the grand steam engine named “La Prieta Linda” (“The Pretty Black Engine”), which was the first to travel through the routes where the beast currently runs.

In one of the communities in the small city a group has been established, named Alfa because to the members of the group it means that it is God who helps them with their day-to-day activities. Currently, the group consists of 10 members:
Nancy- Cosmetics
Rosalia- Clothes and carpentry
Severa- Desserts
Elsa- Cosmetics and clothing
Maresa, Julia- Interior clothing by catalog
Margarita- Food and juices
Dora- Clothing
Virginia- Raising pigs
Abigail- Selling candy and bread

Rosalia is 42 years old. Everyone knows her as “Chalia.” She is married to Miguel Angel, who works as a carpenter. They are the parents of 2 adult children. For 5 years they have lived alone in their home.

Chalia makes a living from helping her husband with carpentry, sanding, varnishing, and measuring the furniture that they produce. Likewise, she began selling clothing on foot. In the evenings after helping her husband with his carpentry and when the sun has gone down a little she goes out to travel the streets to the home of each of her customers to show them the clothing.

With the profits made from carpentry, they have been able to purchase a lot where they have installed a permanent carpenter’s workshop and they do not have to pay rent, which means more profits. She invests the profits obtained from the clothing in the purchase of pants, blouses, and shirts with the goal of offering an extensive assortment to her customers, and overall the profits have served to remodel her home. “While we construct the carpentry workshop we are constructing a small store next to the carpentry workshop to show the clothing and not neglect the activities.”

On this occasion, she will invest this loan in the purchase of pants, blouses, shirts, paintbrushes, and varnish so that the investment is in both activities.

“Thank you for the loans awarded. With each one of them, each of our activities has been strengthened and with the profits we provide a better quality of life to our family.”

*the photograph was taken in Maresa’s home. Chalia is the one dressed in a pink blouse and black capri pants.

loans.use: to purchase: pants, blouses, shirts, paint bushes, and varnish.

loans.name: Kilimanjaro Group

texts.en: Stella, who is in her early 40s, is married with three children who are still in school.  She has been running a grocery store for one year now.  She works from  6 a.m. to 11 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit. This will be Stella's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She will use this loan to buy fast-moving drinks in her grocery store.  She dreams of improving her grocery store. Stella will share this loan with her loan group Kilimanjaro which consists of two members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy fast-moving drinks in her grocery store.

loans.name: Nkaakiti

texts.en: Nkaakiti is 46 years old. She is married with five children. She has had a farming business for five years, growing cereals, and it has been profitable. She will be using the loan to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizer and seeds and manure and hopes this will help her pay school fees. Her hopes and dreams for the future are to educate her children to a higher level.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizer and seeds and manure to help her pay school fees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase certified fertilizers and herbicides to spray his crops for a higher yield.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to make a lot of drinks to sell.

loans.name: Alcides

texts.en: Alcides is a taxi driver who works from Monday to Saturday. He is single and lives with his brothers in La Paz city. Alcides needs another loan to pay for the maintenance of his vehicle. Alcides' constant problem is that his vehicle is old and he doesn't have the money to buy another one. Alcides is still the only one in the family that earns money, so he needs your help again. Alcides would like to buy another vehicle in the future.

loans.use: to pay for the maintenance of his vehicle.

loans.name: El Polvoron Group

texts.es:
En una comunidad donde la pesca y el cultivo de la caña de azúcar juega el papel principal en la economía de la comunidad, las tradiciones y costumbres son mazatecas puesto que en la comunidad se dio el asentamiento de dicha cultura.

Recientemente en una de sus comunidades se formó un grupo llamado el polvorón pues se relaciona con el nombre de la colonia donde radican, los integrantes del grupo son:

Margarita- Comida
Rosario – Ropa 
Herlinda -Refresco
Juliana, Araceli, Florida – Tamales 
Jesús – Café Internet 
Carlota – Tortillas 

Doña Florida es una de las integrantes del polvorón tiene 40 años, está casada con el señor Hernesto  juntos procrearon 4 hijos de los cuales solo dos depende económicamente de ellos, estudian en la escuela de la comunidad, desde niña doña Flor como le conocen en la colonia aprendió de su madre y abuela a elaborar tamales de diferentes estilos siendo los anaranjados los más destacados y sabrosos. 

Desde hace 6 años decidió iniciar con la venta de tamales puesto que los gastos en casa aumentaron y brindarle lo mejor a sus hijos es lo principal para ella y su esposo, dos días a la semana doña Flor prepara la masa, desmenuza la pechuga de pollo, prepara la salsa, lava y seca las hojas de plátano y tlanepa para proceder a pre coser  la maza, envolver la masa con la carne y salsa para envolver la masa y amarrarla con hojas de izote, los acomoda en una vaporera y somete a cocción durante aproximadamente 40 minutos.

Cuando los tamales están listos comienza la segunda parte de la acción los pone en una cubeta, toma unas pinzas y recorre las calles de la comunidad visitando a sus clientes, algunos otros acuden a su casa en busca de los tamales (huaraches, yuca, rancheros, rojos, rancheros, de frijol, dobladas y de elote), sus dos hijos le ayudan a entregar tamales con los clientes más cercanos y en ocasiones le acompañan para cargar la cubeta, como mínimo vende 200 tamales “estoy feliz con mi actividad y con la manera de preservar la comida típica”

El préstamo recibido lo invertirá en la compra de maíz, manteca, chiles y carne continuando con su actividad, con las ganancias apoya a su esposo con los gastos y han podido brindar a sus hijos buena calidad de vida.
Doña Flor comenta que espera poder iniciar con una pequeña tienda de abarrotes o cocina económica y continuara con su venta de tamales.

Los integrantes del grupo agradecen a quienes han hecho posible cada uno de los préstamos.

*Ellos son los integrantes del grupo el polvorón, doña Flor viste un vestido típico de la comunidad.
texts.en:
In a community where fishing and raising sugar cane play the principal role in the economy, the traditions and customs are Mazatec, since there was a settlement of this culture in the community.

Recently in one of the communities, a group called "El Polvorón" was formed, since it is related to the name of the settlement where it is located. The members of the group are: Margarita, who sells food; Rosario, who sells clothing; Herlinda, who sells soft drinks; Juliana, Araceli, and Florida, who sell tamales; Jesús, who has an internet cafe; and Carlota, who sells tortillas. 

Doña Florida is one of the members of "El Polvorón." She is 40 years old. She is married to Señor Hernesto. Together they have four children, of whom only two depend on them economically. They go to school in the community. Since she was a girl, Doña Flor, as she is known in the neighborhood, learned from her mother and grandmother how to make tamales of different types, the orange ones being the most emphasized and flavorful.

Six years ago she decided to begin the sale of tamales, since the household expenses increased, and offering the best to their children is the most important thing for her and her husband. Two days a week Doña Flor prepares the dough, shreds the chicken breast, prepares the sauce, and washes and dries the banana and tlanepa [Mexican pepperleaf] leaves in order to proceed to precook the dough, roll the dough with the meat and sauce in order to wrap the dough and tie it with izote leaves. She places them in a steamer and cooks them for approximately 40 minutes.

When the tamales are ready, she begins the second part of the process. She puts them in a tray, takes some tongs, and goes through the streets of the community, visiting her customers. Some others come to her house in search of the tamales ([of different types]: huaraches, yucca, rancheros, red, bean, folded, and elote). Her two children help her to deliver tamales to nearest customers, and sometimes they accompany her to carry the tray. She sells a minimum or 200 tamales. "I am happy with my business and with this way of preserving [the custom] of traditional food."

She will invest the loan received in the purchase of corn, lard, chiles, and meat, continuing with her business. With the earnings, she helps her husband with the expenses, and they have been able to offer their children a good quality of life.

Doña Flor comments that she hopes to be able to set up a little grocery store or a kitchen that produces reasonably priced food, and she will continue with her sale of tamales.

The members of the group are grateful to those who have made possible each one of the loans. They are the members of the group "El Polvorón." Doña Flor is wearing a traditional dress of the community.

loans.use: to buy corn, lard, chili peppers, and meat

loans.name: Adan

texts.en: Adan is an orphan and he lives with his uncle who is also his godfather. Adan graduated from high school and he started to sell shoes. He works with his friend. He needs a loan to buy merchandise for his business. Adan would like to go to the university in the future but right now he needs help because he helps his uncle with the expenses at his house. Adan is at his house in the picture. He goes to many fairs to sell the shoes.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for his business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more Irish potatoes to sell.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en: Samuson is 36 years old, and married with five children, four of whom attend school. He owns a retail shop and earns additional income from motorcycle transport. He works six days a week. He looks forward to growing his business and opening up new outlets in nearby centres where he has discovered a market. Inadequate capital and price fluctuations are challenges he faces. He describes himself as being honest and hardworking. He has requested a loan to buy maize flour, cooking oil, rice and other items to sell.

loans.use: to buy maize flour, cooking oil, rice and other items to sell.

loans.name: Eliud

texts.en:
Dairy farming is an important source of income and employment for smallholder Kenyan farmers like Eliud. He is 35 years old and has been happily married to Miriam for the last 12 years. They have two children. For the past two years Eliud has operated a two-acre mixed farm in Kigumo village located in the Central province of Kenya. He keeps dairy goats, cattle, and poultry and grows maize, vegetables, and other crops on his farm. He also engages in other side businesses for additional income. He is constantly upgrading and introducing new ways and approaches of doing business to make his farm more sustainable for the environment while still being profitable.

Eliud is seeking a loan to fully incorporate zero-grazing into his farm. The cattle management system on his farm is shifting from being extensive (which is confined to ranches and large-scale farms) to being intensive. The intensive systems are the most predominant and comprise zero-grazing and semi-zero-grazing systems. With your funding, the introduction of zero-grazing will create significant value for Eliud's business. This management system is the most suitable for this farmer, considering his land, labour, and capital. Returns from this investment will be put back into the business to drive its evolution into a modern practice. Your loan will elevate the quality of life for Eliud and his family.

loans.use: to start a zero-grazing unit.

loans.name: Edson

texts.en: Edson is 32 years old and married with three children. He lives in Kasese, Uganda. He owns a butchery and does farming as a side income business. By doing these businesses, he manages to cater for his family by providing them with the basic needs and pay school fees for his children. Edson desires to expand his business plus start up a shop for his wife to also be self employed. He has requested credit to buy cows and goats for slaughtering to sell.

loans.use: to  buy cows and goats for slaughtering to sell.

loans.name: Nabweru Development Group

texts.en: This group is made up of businesswomen and businessmen. Mrs Lydia (second from left) is the group representative. She is married, 42 years old, and the mother of eight children including five girls. She has been selling vegetables for over 10 years. With the loan, she will purchase large quantities of quality vegetables. She has loyal clients who pay on time. The earnings will contribute to savings and  help her husband take care of the family. She and the other group members appreciate the partnership. They are hardworking people.

loans.use: to purchase large quantities of quality vegetables.

loans.name: La Flor De Limón Group

texts.es:
En una comunidad oculta entre árboles y sembradíos de caña, cerca del  río Amapá, donde prevalece la cultura mazateca algunos habitantes acuden al río a lavar la ropa en grandes piedras, el 90% de los habitantes se dedica a trabajar en el campo en la siembra de caña de azúcar, limón y maíz. 

En la comunidad se ha formado un grupo hace 5 años “flor de limón” decidieron ponerle al grupo pues les gusta cuando los arboles florean además de significar producción, el grupo está integrado por:

Alba – Bisutería 
Daniela, Elena -Abarrotes
Edith - Estética
Juana -Refresco
Valeria – Ropa Por Catalogo, Refresco Y Agua Purificada
Isabel – Refacciones Para Carro (Aceite, Líquidos Para Freno)
María – Cosméticos 
Alma – Ropa 

Tener la iniciativa y emprender su propio negocio es lo que caracteriza a Valeria  o Vale como le conocen en la comunidad, está casada con Leonel son padres de una niña de 4 años, “inicie con mi actividad poco después de saber que estaba embarazada pues debíamos prepararnos para los gastos futuros” fue así como vale motivada por su bebe inicio con la venta de ropa interior para dama por catálogo, gracias a las ganancias obtenidas y después de ahorrar lo necesario decidió iniciar con la venta de refresco de diferentes sabores , la venta de agua purificada en garrafón, dichas actividades las realiza en casa de tal manera que no descuida a su familia y continua siendo fuente de ingresos.

Durante la semana vale vende en promedio 30 garrafones de agua pues la zona está un poco retirada, en promedio por semana vende de 6 a 9 rejas de refresco,  acude a comprar el pedido de sus clientas cada 8 o 15 días, cobra los fines de semana , mientras ella reparte o sale a cobrar su esposo es quien se encarga de los refrescos, para vale los prestamos han significado una gran oportunidad de crecimiento en cada una de sus actividades puesto que el capital invertido es mayor y mientras mayor sea la inversión mayor son las ganancias “ingrese en el 2013 al grupo y estoy contenta de pertenecer a él , de cada préstamo que he recibido pues poco a poco he ido creciendo con mis actividades”

En esta ocasión vale invertirá el préstamo en la compra refrescos y 30 galones de agua pues con la ola de calor sus clientes consumen el agua y refresco en mayor cantidad.

El grupo agradece a Visión F México y KIVA  por cada uno de los préstamos que les han sido otorgados.

*Ellas son las integrantes del grupo, los niños que se aprecian en la fotografía son hijos de las clientas, Vale es quien viste blusa color melón, la sonrisa en su rostro siempre le acompaña.
texts.en:
In a community hidden between trees and sugar cane, close to the Amapá river where the Mazateca culture predominates some of the inhabitants come to the river to wash their clothing on large rocks. 90% if the inhabitants work in the fields growing sugar cane, lemons and corn. Five years ago a group formed in this community and the name "flor de limón” was chosen for the group as they like when the trees are in flower. Besides this it signifies production.

The group is made up of :
Alba - jewellery
Daniela and Elena - groceries
Edith - a beauty salon
Juana - soft drinks
Valeria – clothing sales by catalog, soft drinks and purified water
Isabel – car repairs (oil, brake fluid)
María – cosmetics
Alma – clothing

To have the initiative to start her own business is what is characteristic of Valeria or Vale as she is known in the community. She is married to Leonel and they are the parents of a 4 year old daughter. "I started my business shortly after learning that I was pregnant as we had to prepare for future expenses". That was how Vale motivated by her baby started to sell woman's lingerie by catalog. Thanks to the profits she obtained and when she had saved what she needed she decided to sell soft drinks of different flavors, and the sale of large containers of bottled water. These businesses she does at her house so she can take care of her family and continue with her sources of income.

During a week Vale sells an average of 30 containers of water as the area is a bit isolated. On the average she sells 6 to 9 cases of soft drinks. She goes to purchase the orders from her clients every week or two and she collects on weekends. When she is out distributing or out collecting money her husband takes care of the soft drink sales. For Vale the loans have given her a great opportunity to grow in each of her businesses as her invested capital is greater and the larger the investment the greater are her profits. "I joined the communal bank in 2013 and I am happy to belong to it as with each loan that she has received my business has grown little by little"

At this time Vale will invest the loan in buying soft drinks and 30 gallons of water as with the heat wave her clients consume a greater amount of soft drinks and water.

The group is grateful to VisiónFund México and Kiva for each of the loans they have been awarded.

"These are the members of the group. The children who appear in the photo are children of the members. Vale is wearing the pink blouse and the smile that she always has on her face".

loans.use: to buy soft drinks and 30 gallons of water.

location.town: Paso Rincon, San Juan Bautista Tuxtepec, Oaxaca

loans.name: Phares

texts.en:
Phares is 36 years of age, and very passionate and diligent about farming. He is considered a pacesetter when it comes to farming in his village of Kirege, in the Chuka area of Kenya. Having done mixed farming for the past five years, he has gained much experience and offers free extension services to young upcoming farmers. He is happily married and is blessed with two handsome boys.

Phares enjoys generating income from selling milk, his harvest, and produce from his farm. He finds dairy farming very fulfilling, but the main challenge he faces is not being able to properly feed his dairy cows. He is seeking a loan to buy a chaff cutter. Through the loan he will be able to cut hay into small pieces before mixing it with other forage to feed his cattle. The chaff cutter will aid his cattle in digestion and will prevent his dairy cattle from rejecting any part of their food. Proper feeding of cattle is one of the most important factors in maintaining high yield production of milk. Through proper feeding, his cows will produce more milk and this will translate to more profits and improved living standards.

When he was asked how this loan will benefit his family, Phares said “more income.” Profits from the loan will be used to fully repay the loan and improve standards of living for his parents, family, and his school-going children.

loans.use: to purchase a chaff cutter.

loans.name: Kafando Angèle Group

texts.fr: Angèle est une femme mariée mère de 4 enfants.Elle à 39 ans et exerces l'activité de couture et broderie depuis 16 ans.Son atout est qu'elle fait  de la bonne couture et les  clients apprécient.Elle à déjà pris le crédit 14 fois à acfime et respecte ses engagements. Elle veux le crédit pour acheter des accessoires de couture (filon 25000f, collant 75000f, doublure 150000f) et prêt à porter 250000f a fin de faire face a ses commandes.
texts.en:
Angèle is a married mother of four. She is 39 years old and has had a business involving sewing and embroidering for sixteen years. Her advantage is that she sews correctly, and her customers appreciate this.

Angèle has already had a loan fourteen times at ACFIME, and she respects her commitments. She wants the loan to purchase some sewing accessories (filon 25,000 francs, glue 75,000 francs, lining 150,000 francs) and ready-to-wear pieces 250,000 francs, in order to cope with her special orders.

loans.use: to purchase sewing accessories (thread, glue, lining) and ready-to-wear clothing

loans.name: Ambrose

texts.en:
Ambrose is newly married and has a child. He is a hardworking farmer and born salesperson from the North Rift area of Kenya. He raises mainly livestock and farms tea for a living. His wife runs a small retail shop and helps him with the work in the house as well as on the farm.

Like most fathers, Ambrose wants the best for his family and shows this by continually looking for ways to generate more income. Now he is applying for a 35,000 KES loan through Kiva's field partner Juhudi Kilimo to buy cereals from a group of local farmers at harvest time. He will buy them at current market prices and then sell them later at a higher price. Given that Ambrose knows how to arrange sales more easily than regular farmers, his work gives the farmers a reliable buyer and frees them to focus on the part they are good at: production.

Income generated from other income sources will be used to make his initial loan installments as he waits for his big break. Income from the sale of cereals will help him meet both business and household expenses such as food and water.

loans.use: to buy cereals from a group of local farmers at harvest time

loans.name: Anecito

texts.en:
Anecito is 69, married and has adult children. He is an active member of Kiva's field partner Paglaum MPC who enjoys all the perks of being a member. He said he's secure financially knowing he can always turn to the cooperative, but he also wants to be prepared for unforeseen life events. For this reason he avails himself of the life insurance offered by the coop.

Now that Anecito’s one-year life insurance policy has expired, he has applied for a 5,000 PHP loan to continue his insurance coverage. He believes that it is better to be prepared than to be held by the neck by unexpected circumstances.

loans.use: to continue his life insurance coverage

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a rural smallhold crop farmer in Kitale area of Kenya. He owns a small farm located right next to a river. His land is prime for horticultural farming because the soil stays moist throughout the year, and he makes the best use of it by also raising cattle.

Paul stated that he enjoys farming because it provides food and income for his family. He identified that his major challenge is high cost of production. He is seeking a loan to buy agricultural inputs. With the borrowed money, he plans to buy improved seeds and fertilizer as he prepares for planting season.
With this loan, Paul will have the right quantity and quality of agricultural inputs to produce food in the coming season. Your investment will improve his chances for a successful harvest.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs and cereals

loans.name: Erick

texts.en:
Erick is a smallhold farmer based in Maara village in Central Kenya. He owns a three acre piece of land that he uses to grow maize and keep dairy animals. He has also planted 100 trees on it for aesthetic appearance and environmental health. Not only does the land provide him with capital for his business, but also a home for his family. He is blessed to have three children with a wife to whom he has stayed married for more than twenty years.

Erick is seeking a loan to purchase cereals. The cereals he is seeking serve to replenish stock for his food and his business. The demand for cereals in the market, only a few kilometers from Erick's home, is increasing. Farmers in the area are rushing to grow more cereal crops. By placing himself in a position of supplying cereal seeds and still being a cereal farmer, he gets to enjoy profits from selling inputs and crop harvests.

He is very pragmatic and considers himself more hardworking than others. Your loan will directly elevate Erick’s livelihood. He strives to give his children a better life than the tough upbringing he grew up in.

loans.use: to buy cereals.

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio is 69 years old, married and lives in Mobod, Oroquieta City in Misamis Occidental province. He owns and operates a sari-sari, or convenience store, which he has run since he retired from his work as a government employee.

Rogelio has applied for a 5,000 PHP loan to restock his store with consumable items such as canned goods, noodles, coffee and milk, among other things. He is grateful to Kiva's field partner Paglaum MPC’s assistance for its support of his business.

loans.use: to restock his store with consumable items, such as canned goods, noodles, coffee and milk, among other things.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a rural smallhold crop farmer in the Ndaragwa area of Kenya. He is married and has 4 children. Besides crop farming, Charles also does dairy farming and runs a wood workshop. The key lesson he has taken away from 22 years of being a farmer and a carpenter is that in life, you get what you give.

Charles is seeking a loan to buy quality agricultural inputs. With the borrowed money, he plans to buy improved seeds and quality fertilizer to enhance his farm’s productivity and the quality of his produce.
With your loan, having quality agricultural inputs will increase Charles’ chances for a successful harvest.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas is 43 years old. He is a farmer by nature and he has worked as a manager on different farms. Today, thanks to the coming of Kiva lenders and Juhudi Kilimo to his territory, he can dream and aspire to better things for his wife and their children.

Nicholas is an accomplished farmer from the Nkubu area of Kenya and commands a lot of respect. He loves and cherishes his family. Nicholas and his wife work as a team, supporting each other, and have practiced mixed farming for the past five years. Nicholas often says, “I have always had an affinity for farming, and it runs in my blood.” Because of the liking that he has for farming, he has even nicknamed one of his cows, which makes him a very proud farmer, especially when he is milking his cows. From his dairy cow, he is able to get between 10 and 20 liters of milk a day, and this helps him support his family.

Nicholas also practices crop farming, but he has not been making good profits because of poor farming inputs; that is why he is kindly seeking a loan to buy farm inputs and seeds to start horticulture farming. Through the loan, he will be able to buy high quality seeds, good fertilizer, and pesticides that he will use to greatly improve his crop production. Modern farming requires the use of modern techniques and therefore, using high-quality seeds will assure him of a bumper harvest and increased profit levels.

Nicholas is very visionary, and his goal for the season is to boost his crop production and be able to get more crop output than the previous year. All this can be achieved through the lenders’ help and goodwill. Nicholas believes that through the loan, he will turn around his family life and be able to give his children a solid education. This loan will be Nicholas’s way out of poverty.

loans.use: to buy high quality seeds, good fertilizer, and pesticides that he will use to greatly improve his crop production.

loans.name: Arcoiris De Colores Group

texts.es:
El silbido de la bestia anuncia la llegada a la pequeña ciudad y con el migrantes que persiguen toda costa cumplir el suelo americano, quienes viven a orillas de la vía suelen aventarles bolsas con comida pues si se bajan de la bestia pueden perder el viaje y esperar a que vuelva a pasar el tren.

En una de las comunidades se formó un grupo llamado Arcoíris de Colores, los integrantes eligieron el nombre pues es poco común ver un arcoíris en la novia del sol, los integrantes del grupo y su actividad son:

Maribel, Margarita, Jorge, Arcelia - comida
Reyna –tacos 
Liliana - Papelería
Maria –calzado
 
Liliana tiene 27 años, recientemente se convirtió en madre soltera de un pequeño de 4 meses de edad, Lili como todos le conocen se ha dedicado a la venta de novedades y refrescos  desde hace 9 años, con las ganancias percibidas apoya a su madre con los gastos de la casa y desde que se enteró de su embarazo empezó ahorrar para los gastos del parto, hace 2 meses Lili es la encargada de la papelería que tenía su madre “ mi mama me traspaso la papelería a la que había dedicado 15 años de su vida para que funde el patrimonio de mi hijo, estoy agradecida con ella por su apoyo incondicional”

La papelería brinda servicio a partir de las 8 de la mañana a 8 de la noche pues así lo demandan los clientes, esta vez Lili ha solicitado el préstamo para pagar parte del pedido de temporada (libretas, cuadernos, lapiceros, lápiz, goma, sacapuntas, plastilina, Resistol) pues las clases se acercan y con ellas las ventas aumentan.

Lili ha fusionado la papelería y los artículos para regalos de tal manera que se dedica ambas actividades sin descuidar ninguna de las dos ni a su pequeño, sus planes a futuro son ampliar la papelería e incluir una mercería pues caminar a rayo de sol para ir por un botón, hilo o elástico  es cansado y sus clientes le han sugerido esa actividad y su mama está dispuesta apoyarla además de que el local donde está la papelería es propio por lo que las ganancias son mayores.

“gracias por el nuevo préstamo, por ayudarnos para la realización de nuestros sueños, gracias a cada una de las personas que lo ha hecho posible” son las palabras de agradecimiento del grupo arcoíris de colores.

*la fotografía fue tomada en el patio de la casa de Jorge, Lili es quien viste blusa color azul con lunares anaranjados.
texts.en:
The whistle of the train [La Bestia] announces its arrival to the small city, and with it come the migrants that are chasing the american dream at all costs. Those who live on the edges of the railroad usually throw them bags of food because if they get off of the train they could miss the trip and have to wait until it comes around again.

In one of the communities, a group was formed named Arcoíris de Colores [Rainbow of Colors]. The members chose the name because it is very uncommon to see a rainbow in the city. The members of the group and their occupations are:

Maribel, Margarita, Jorge, Arcelia - Food sales
Reyna - Taco sales
Liliana - Stationery store
Maria - Shoe sales

Liliana is 27 years old, and recently became a single mother of a baby that is 4 months old. Lili, as she is called, has earned a living selling novelties and soft drinks for 9 years. With the income she earned she helped her mother with the home expenses, and from the time she found out she was pregnant she started to save for the costs of the childbirth. For the last two months she has been in charge of the stationery store that her mother owns. She says, "My mom gave me the store where she had spent 15 years of her life as a form of inheritance for my son. I'm grateful to her for her unconditional support."

The stationery store is open from 8 in the morning until 8 at night because this is what the customers require. This time Lili is requesting a loan to pay for part of the seasonal order (booklets, notebooks, pens, pencils, erasers, pencil sharpeners, clay, and glue). School is about to begin, and with that, the sales increase.

Lili has consolidated the stationery store and the novelty items in such a way that she can work on both activities without neglecting either of the two, nor her baby. Her future plans are to expand the stationery store and include sewing goods because walking to another neighborhood for a button, string or elastic is too tiring, and her customers have suggested this to her, and her mother is willing to support her. Also, the location where the store is located belongs to them, so the profits are greater.

"Thank you for the new loan, and for helping us realize our dreams. Thank you to each person that has made it possible," are the words of thanks from the group Arcoíris de Colores.

*The photograph was taken on the patio of Jorge's house. Lili is the one dressed in the blue blouse with orange polka dots.

loans.use: to buy booklets, notebooks, pens, pencils, erasers, pencil sharpeners, clay, and glue.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Most of the Kenyan people find an opportunity to make a living and progress through practicing mixed farming. Such is the case of Joyce who at the age of 45 has a small parcel of land. Joyce is a very hardworking, very honest and warm-hearted farmer who hails from the Kapsowar area of Kenya, an area that has one of the best weather patterns on earth for farming.

Joyce is the proud mother of a lovely family whom she adores and always protects. Joyce's upbringing was very challenging, and because of this she promised herself that she would work hard to get out of poverty. That is why she started farming six years ago. Through farming, she has been able to earn a decent income. Joyce is the breadwinner of her family, and this really pushes her to work hard so that her children will have a bright future and her parents will have a comfortable life.

Joyce is seeking a loan to buy seeds and start horticultural farming so that she can use the excess space on her land. She dreams of buying more land and increasing her horticultural farming. Accessing funds is very difficult for a woman in Africa, but through institutions such as Juhudi Kilimo and Kiva, Joyce is optimistic that her dream will be realized and her life will completely change. Through the income from horticultural farming Joyce will assure her children a bright future and will be able to pay tuition fees for her siblings who depend on her. Through your loan, the promise of supporting small-scale farmers will be achieved.

For Joyce, nothing is impossible. She wants to continue working to fulfill her dream of becoming the largest horticulture farmer so that she can enjoy a good quality life.

loans.use: to start horticultural farming

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy poultry

loans.name: Kris Avantou

texts.en:
Jean Gary (first name) is the representative of a community-based VSLA that is interested in linking with a microfinance institution.

He created this group one year ago with 16 men and 14 women. 70% of his group are street sellers. They buy food products in bulk and retail. Jean Gary (right) is pictured with Aniece (middle) and Bernard (left).

This loan, if granted, will allow them to generate profits for their children's education and for empowering the women's power to purchase.

loans.use: to buy home products in bulk to retail to customers.

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en: Perlita is managing her eatery business in Poblacion II, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She mastered the business when she and her husband were in the early years of their marriage. The business has been doing well in supporting the needs of the family. She has local customers and also accepts catering for additional income. Recently she requested a loan to purchase more kilos of meat and spices for her eatery business. She wants to expand her business and would be very happy to open a small canteen at a nearby school.

loans.use: to purchase more kilos of meat and spices for her eatery business

loans.name: El Regreso Group

texts.es:
Los habitantes son hospitalarios, amables, cálidos tal cual es el clima de la novia del sol,  en abril se dan cita en el carnaval (recorrido en carros alegóricos por las calles principales de la ciudad) en él participan distintas comparsas y actualmente actores y actrices de televisa.

“El Regreso”  lleva por nombre un grupo integrado por 8 mujeres trabajadoras, que buscan el bienestar de su familia, el nombre se debe a la acción que han realizado 7 de las integrantes del grupo al formar un nuevo grupo y solicitar nuevamente préstamos a Visión F México.

Juana –Zapatos, Papelería, Ropa Y Bolsas De Mano.
María -Ropa 
Luisa- ropa y servicio de costura
Laura, Amelia -Comida 
Leidy –Zapatos, Bolsas Y Carteras
Roció-Abarrotes Y Tortillería
Ana - Zapatos.

Doña Luisa es una mujer muy trabajadora, tiene  71 años de edad estudio la primaria, está casada con el señor  Aizides,  son padres de 8 hijos quienes los han convertido en abuelos y los nietos en bisabuelos  transformándose en una familia numerosa, desde hace 38 años doña Licha como le conocen se ha dedicado a vender ropa para dama y costurar ropa ajena, comenta que la necesidad de aprender a costurar surgió por sus hijos a quienes tenía que componer la ropa o mandar hacer el vestuario para los bailables sin pensar que se convertiría en su actividad.

Durante los 38 años que tiene de experiencia en la maquina ha costurado vestidos para novia, quinceañera, primera comunión, confirmación, para clausuras escolares y bailables todos ellos de acuerdo a los gustos de sus clientes quienes  realizan sus pedidos con tiempo de anticipación.

Las ganancias percibidas le permitieron brindar educación a sus hijos, remodelar la casa, ha comprado 5 máquinas, dado mantenimiento a las maquinas, de igual manera les han permitido ofrecer buena calidad de vida a su familia, actualmente con las ganancias solventa sus gastos personales   y reinvierte en sus actividades.

Doña Licha ha costurado desde entonces en la comodidad de su recamara pues comenta que es donde se siente más a gusto los trazos los realiza en una mesa, los cortes  los realiza sobre su cama, al lado de su máquina están las agujas, alfileres, hilos, botones, cierres y tijeras comenta que de tal manera encuentra todo lo que necesita, para cumplir a sus clientes con su pedido costura durante el día, la tarde y en ocasiones durante la noche.

Los préstamos que le han sido otorgados a doña Lili los ha invertido en la compra de camisas, faldas, blusas,  pantalones  al igual que alfileres, cierres, hilos, agujas, bies  y telas continuando con sus actividades, en esta ocasión el préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de faldas, pantalones, blusas, camisas y playeras.

“Gracias por el apoyo que nos brindan al otorgarnos los préstamos para favorecer nuestras actividades”
*la fotografía fue tomada en el espacio donde doña Lili costura, sobre la cama un vestido que estaba terminando, ella es quien viste blusa floreada y falda anaranjada.
texts.en:
The inhabitants are hospitable, friendly, and warm, as is the climate of La Novia del Sol. In April they schedule the Carnaval (parades in decorated floats through the principal streets of the city), and different troupes participate in it, now including television actors and actresses.

A group formed by eight hard-working women who seek the well-being of their families bears the name "El Regreso." The name comes from the action taken by seven of the members of the group to form a new group and apply again to Vision Fund México for loans.

[The members are]: Juana, who sells shoes, stationery, clothing, and handbags; Maria, who sells clothing; Luisa, who sells clothing and does dress-making; Laura and Amelia, who sell food; Leidy, who sells shoes, bags, and wallets; Roció, who sells groceries and has a tortilla shop; and Ana, who sells shoes. 

Doña Luisa is a very hard-working woman. She is 71 years old. She attended primary school. She is married to Señor Aizides. They are the parents of eight children, who have made them grandparents, and the grandchildren have made them great-grandparents, transforming them into a numerous family. For 38 years, Doña Licha, as she is known, has sold clothing for women and made clothing for others. She comments that the need to learn sewing arose from her children, for whom she had to make clothing or have it made for dances, without thinking that it would become her business.

During the 38 years of experience with the machine, she has made dresses for brides, quinceañeras [15-year-old girls' birthday celebrations], first communions, confirmations, school completions, and dances, all according to the tastes of her customers, who place their orders in advance.

The earnings that she has received allowed her to offer an education to her children and remodel the house. She has bought five machines and maintained the machines, and in the same way, this has allowed her to offer a good quality of life to her family. Now she pays her personal expenses with the earnings and reinvests in her businesses.

Doña Licha has sewn since then in the comfort of her bedroom, since she comments that it is where she feels most at ease. She makes the designs on a table. She does the cutting on her bed. Alongside her machine are the needles, pins, threads, buttons, closures, and scissors. She comments that in this way she finds everything that she needs. To complete her customers' orders, she sews during the day, the afternoon, and sometimes during the night.

The loans that have been granted to Doña Licha have been invested in the purchase of shirts, skirts, blouses, and pants, as well as pins, closures, thread, needles, bias bindings, and fabrics, continuing with her activities. At this time, she will invest the loan in the purchase of skirts, pants, blouses, shirts, and t-shirts.

"Thank you for the support that was offered to us by granting us the loans to help our businesses."

The photograph was taken in the space where Doña Licha sews. On the bed is a dress that she was finishing. She is the one wearing a flowered blouse and an orange skirt.

loans.use: to buy skirts, pants, blouses, shirts, and t-shirts

loans.name: Rakiswiligri Group

texts.fr: Eveline, est une femme âgée de 39 ans mariée mère de 6 enfants. Elle exerce son activité de vendeuse de dolo depuis 4 ans. Son atout c’est qu’elle est dynamisme, battante elle prépare le dolo (boisson traditionnelle accolisée fait à base du mil) elle-même, son dolo est bien fait, un cadre propre. Elle est connue dans son quartier a cause de la qualité de son dolo. Elle est à 12ème crédit à ACFIME et à toujour bien payer.Elle sollicite le crédit pour acheter 150 000f de mil et 50000f de bois.
texts.en: Eveline is a 39-year-old woman who is the married mother of six. She has been operating her business selling “dolo” for four years. Her advantage is that she is energetic and determined. She makes dolo (a traditional alcoholic beverage made from millet) by herself. Her dolo is well-made and done properly. She is known in her district for the quality of her dolo. Eveline is on her 12th loan at ACFIME and has always paid it back correctly. She is requesting the loan to purchase 150,000 francs of millet and 50,000 francs of firewood.

loans.use: to purchase millet and wood

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Despite the importance of agriculture most of the financial institutions shy away from lending to farmers, but Juhudi Kilimo is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Kenyan farmers.

Meet Beatrice, an ever-smiling, hardworking and honest mother who is 30 years of age! She hails from the Kapsowar area of Kenya. She is the proud mother of a lovely family. She loves and treasures her children and will go the extra mile to make sure that they are comfortable. Beatrice’s primary source of income has come from selling milk, crop farming, and poultry farming. Through these ventures she has been able to earn a decent income. She is a very determined and dedicated farmer who has been farming for 10 years, and throughout she has never regretted going into farming.

Although this humble mum has been making profits, not everything has been “a bed of roses." She faces financial challenges and because the Kapsowar area has proven a ready market for farm produce, she is kindly seeking a loan to buy seeds so as to plant them and increase crop production and later sell them once they are ready for harvesting. Beatrices’s upbringing was challenging and she has faced many economic problems. But this ever-smiling mum has been making great improvements, and she believes that through your loan she will be able to realize her goal of improving her living conditions and transforming her life.

Through Juhudi Kilimo, Beatrice has received training and proven to be honest and disciplined with finances. She intends to fully repay the loan with the profits from her business. Beatrice is quite visionary and with her accumulated profits hopes she will be able to sell more farm produce that will boost her income and completely turn her life around.

loans.use: to buy seeds so as to increase her farm production.

loans.name: Jayamani

texts.en:
Jayamani is a rural hardworking woman of 52 years. She is married to Sunil, a 46-year-old farmer. They live in Dakshin Parengerpar, a small village of Falakata, in Alipurduar district, West Bengal, India. They are blessed with four grown up children (one son and three daughters).

Jayamani’s husband is a very hard-working man. He cultivates mainly paddy rice. Sunil has a lot of knowledge of cultivation and always offers quality products. They supply the harvest to the rice dealers in the nearby market. In order to strengthen the business and respond to client demand.

Jayamani is requesting a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) for purchasing good quality paddy fertilizers, pesticides, and seeds, and to cover the operational costs. Their goal is to increase their business activity.

With this investment, at the end of the harvest, they will be able to have a better production, and with these earnings, they will be able to improve their family’s quality of life.

Jayamani is very thankful for Kiva and BJS.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers for their existing paddy cultivation.

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.en: Esperanza is 63 years old and a widow with four grownup children. She has been a wholesaler of bananas in their town for almost 20 years. From this longtime experience of selling, she already has a lot of knowledge in dealing in this kind of business. Even though there are many competitors in the town, Esperanza still gets more customers than the others do due to her good salesmanship and characteristic effort. She has been successful over the years and manages to save more money for her family. For now, Esperanza is planning to buy a parcel of land in order to manage a new business which is creating a small pigpen for additional income in the near future. To fund this project, she needs additional capital to purchase 300 kilos of banana for wholesale, so she has requested a loan from Paglaum MPC.

loans.use: to purchase 300 kilos of bananas for wholesale.

loans.name: Gleceria

texts.en: Gleceria has a copra (coconut meat converted to cooking oil) production business which she inherited from her parents. She is 62 years old now and a widow with grownup children that help her manage this type of business. She has high demands of copra from the cooking oil industry so she needs to increase her production. To help her financially, she is asking for a loan from Paglaum MPC to purchase additional coconut for copra (coconut meat converted to cooking oil) production.

loans.use: to purchase additional coconut for copra (coconut meat converted to cooking oil) production

loans.name: Gueswende Group

texts.fr: Oumoul est âgée de 31 ans mariée mère d’un enfant. Elle exerce son activité de tisseuse depuis 5 ans. Ce qui fait marcher son activité c’est qu’elle est disponible et propose des pagne différents variétés ; en plus de ça ses prix sont abordable et des pagnes de grande qualité. Elle veut le prêt pour acheter les pagnes tissés à 400 000 f et le faso danfani à 300 000 f. L’utilité du prêt c’est de pouvoir approvisionner sa boutique afin de renforcer son activité. Elle a déjà reçu le prêt 5 fois et à rembourser aux dates prévues à ACFIME.
texts.en:
Oumoul, aged 31, is a married mother of one child. She has been operating her fabrics business for five years. What drives her business is that she is available and offers different varieties of 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa); in addition to this, her prices are affordable for ‘pagne’ cloth of great quality.

Oumoul wants this loan to purchase woven ‘pagne’ cloth at 400,000 francs and ‘faso danfani’ cloth at 300,000 francs. The loan use is for stocking up her shop in order to bolster her business. She has already had a loan five times and repaid them as expeccted, at ACFIME.

loans.use: to purchase woven 'pagne' and 'faso danfani" (traditionnel fabic of Burkina Faso)

loans.name: Bebi

texts.en:
Bebi is a 37-year-old married woman who lives with her husband, Kulen, aged 44 years. Bebi studied up to grade 6, but her husband is illiterate and can only sign his name. She is a loving mother of two children. One of them is studying in grade 10 and another one is below school going age. They live in the small village of Falakata in the district Alipurduar.

Her husband engaged in agriculture work. Being a housewife, Bebi is very enthusiastic about her husband’s business and helps her husband to earn a reasonable amount of money to support her family. Now she and her husband want to expand their business, but they do not have a sufficient amount to invest in their business.

Therefore Bebi has applied for a loan to cultivate paddy and she wants to sell the harvest produce to the local market. The demand of paddy is very high in her locality, and thus they decided to grow this profitable crop. The loan will be used to purchase paddy seeds and fertilizers and bear the other operational costs for farming paddies.

Both Bebi and her husband dream that in future they will be able to built a concrete house with the profit generated from the business.

Her full thanks go to BJS as well as Kiva for giving the loan.

loans.use: to purchase good quality paddy seeds and fertilizers and to bear the operational costs for cultivating paddy.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia is 33 years old, married, and lives in Poblacion II, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She manages a "lechon" production business where she has customers who are local or from neighboring towns. She's making good sales especially on special occasions like Christmas, New Year's, Graduation and Fiesta, so she needs to buy pigs from local hog growers. To help her financially, she asks for a loan to purchase additional heads of pigs for her "lechon" (roasted whole pig) business.

loans.use: to purchase additional heads of pigs for her "lechon" (roasted whole pig) business.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en: Anita is a strong-willed woman who will do anything for her family. She is 65 years old, married and lives in Tuyabang Bajo, Oroquieta City. She operates a hog-raising business which is primarily financed by Paglaum MPC. The business gives her a quarterly income of approximately PHP 15,000 that sufficiently provides for the needs of her family. Recently, she requested another loan to buy piglets and purchase bags of animal feeds.

loans.use: to buy piglets and purchase bags of animal feeds.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en: Lorna is 51 years old. She is from Tuyabang Bajo, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She has a parcel of land that she cultivates and grows vegetables that she supplies to the local market. She is actively participating in the various programs and services that the coop offers. She hopes to live comfortably, with a decent house, for which she applied for a loan to purchase plywood, nails, and sticks. She hopes to maintain her membership in good standing with a good repayment record. It matters that she has been given a priority as a microfinance member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC). She is thankful when all her financing needs of her retailing business are supported by PMPC.

loans.use: to purchase plywood, nails, and sticks for her house.

loans.name: Andresa

texts.en: Andresa signed up for her membership with PMPC and obtained the needed capital to start up a sari-sari store business. She is thankful for the capital that was extended to a small-time borrower like her. Andresa is able to turn the tide in her favor and is making good sales these days. She wants to take advantage of this good fortune. Recently she took a loan to restock her store with basic commodities like canned goods, oil, and soy sauce. In the future, she hopes to build a decent home for the family.

loans.use: to restock her store with items like canned goods, oil, and soy sauce.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en: Mary Ann makes a good income from her farming activities in Dolipos Bajo, Oroquieta City. This is how she supports her family and is able to send her children to school. She wants to increase her farm yield especially since she has a high cost of living since her children entered college. Mary Ann approached Paglaum for a loan to purchase a knapsack sprayer for insecticides and bags of fertilizers. She has high hopes that she will have good produce this cropping season.

loans.use: to purchase a knapsack sprayer for insecticides and bags of fertilizers.

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en: Liezel has signed up for her membership with PMPC and requested the needed capital to start up a sari-sari store business to support her husband in providing for the needs of her family. She is thankful for the capital that PMPC extends to a small-time loaner like her. Liezel is able to turn the tide in her favor and has made good sales these days. She wants to take advantage of the good fortune. Recently, she requested a loan to restock her store with basic commodities like canned goods, oil, and soy sauce. In the future, she hopes to have a decent home for the family.

loans.use: to restock store with basic commodities like canned goods, oil, and soy sauce.

loans.name: Matilde

texts.en: Matilde is a 65-year-old widow with grown-up children from Lumbayao, Aloran-Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is actively participating in various activities of the cooperative now that she has retired from public service. To maintain her healthy disposition as she ages, she needs to take maintenance medicines and vitamins. She has asked for a loan from Paglaum MPC to purchase maintenance medicines.

loans.use: to purchase maintenance medicines

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en: Mercedes is 72 years old, single and lives in Dullan, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is a retired public school teacher who devoted her entire life to teaching young minds. Now that she has retired, she spends most of her time in cooperative activities where she is a microfinance member. Recently, she requested a loan of PHP 30,000 to purchase maintenance medicines and vitamins.

loans.use: to purchase maintenance medicines and vitamins.

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en: Elvie is managing her eatery business in Mohon, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. This has been doing well supporting the needs of the family. She has local customers  and passengers since her eatery is located near the bus stop. Recently, she requested a loan to purchase more kilos of meat and spices for her eatery business. She wants to expand her business and would be very happy to open a small canteen at a nearby school.

loans.use: to purchase more kilos of meat and spices for her eatery business.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
In the Philippines, sari-sari stores are everywhere. Sari-sari (a term used for variety) stores sell different kinds of products from biscuits, candies, canned goods, noodles, products used for personal hygiene and the like, which are involved in every individual’s daily living. This is considered as one of the most common businesses built by ordinary people since it provides commodities for people. 

With this fact, Milagros was enticed to get in touch with this kind of business. She is 51 years old, married to Dioscoro and a resident of Santa Barbara, Iloilo, Philippines. They are working with determination to pursue the needs of their family. The income they get from the store helps them for their daily expenditures. 

However, the profits they get from the business are sometimes insufficient. It is because at times, she finds it hard to maintain supplies of various products due to financial instability. This is why she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan that she will utilize to buy additional products for her inventory. With more products displayed in her store, she can ably have a greater increase in her income. 

In due time, she hopes that she grows in progress and that her business will boost its sales. Through this, she can earn and save money for a house someday if God will allow. 

She meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is comprised of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise products for her inventory.

loans.name: Sugr-Nooma Koanga Group

texts.fr:
Mr BANGRE est responsable du groupe SUGR-NOOMA KOANGA. Il est marié et père de 02 enfants. Le plus âgé a 06 ans et le moins âgé a 01 an. 01 enfant va à l’école et il a 05 personnes en charge.
Mr fait de l’élevage depuis 05 ans. Il s’approvisionne dans les marchés environnants.
Avec l’argent octroyé, il compte acheter 25 poules.
Il veut utiliser les bénéfices du prêt pour réinvestir dans son activité. Il ambitionne devenir un grand éleveur.
texts.en:
Mr. BANGRE is the official of the group SUGR-NOOMA KOANGA. He is a married father of two children. The elder is 6 years old, and the younger is 1. One child goes to school. He has five persons to support.

Mr. BANGRE has been a livestock farmer for five years. He gets his supplies from nearby markets.

With the money granted, he intends to purchase 25 hens. He wants to use the profits from the loan to reinvest in his business. His ambition is to become a major livestock farmer.

loans.use: to purchase 25 chickens

loans.name: Allah Kabo Group

texts.fr: Justine, âgée de 28 ans marié. Elle exerce son activité depuis 4 ans. Ce qui fait marcher son activité c’est l’emplacement de son lieu de vente de l’atiéké, elle fait bien son atiéké et est très propre elle veille à ce que sont lieu soit agréable à tout le monde. Elle veut le prêt pour acheter l’atiéké à 75 000 f, le poisson à 50 000 f et de l’alloco à 10 000 f, le reste c’est dans les autres ingrédients. L’utilité du prêt c’est de s’approvisionner en quantité suffisante pour renforcer son activité afin de satisfaire ses clients. Elle a déjà reçu le prêt deux fois et à rembourser aux dates prévues à ACFIME.
texts.en:
Justine, aged 28, is married. She has been operating her business for four years. What drives her business is her location for selling atiéké [made from fermented cassava]. She makes a good atiéké and is very clean. She oversees her location, so that it is pleasant for everyone.

Justine wants this loan to purchase atiéké at 75,000 francs; fish at 50,000 francs; and some alloco [fried slices of plantain] at 10,000 francs. The rest is for other ingredients. The loan use is to stock up with sufficient amounts to bolster her business, so as to satisfy her customers. Justine has already had a loan twice and repaid them on the expected dates, at ACFIME.

loans.use: to purchase atiéké, fish, alloco, and other ingredients autres ingrédients.

loans.name: Lupercio

texts.en: Lupercio has been a microfinance member of Paglaum MPC for almost 12 years. He and his wife have been tilling their own land for a farming activity that primarily provides for the needs of his family. Lupercio then signed up for membership with Paglaum MPC and had requested financial assistance through its loan services. Lupercio is grateful for the trust the coop had extended to him and was able to buy the neighboring parcel of land. He successfully repaid the loan, and this cropping season he asked for another loan to augment his production. The amount of PHP 22,000 is intended to purchase bags of fertilizers and bottles of insecticides. He is hopeful that he can have a good harvest this season so that he can repay his loan with the cooperative ahead of schedule.

loans.use: to purchase bags of fertilizers and bottles of insecticides

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en: Milagros has been doing a lot of preparation for the post-harvest operations of her palay in Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She wants to ensure that she will have ample time for the threshing, drying, storage and processing of her harvest to make way for another cropping season. She presented her proposal to Paglaum MPC and requested a loan. Milagros hopes to see all of her children finish their degree and have stable careers.

loans.use: to pay for post-harvest operations.

loans.name: La Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
En una comunidad del Estado de Mexico, se conformo un grupo con el nombre de La Nueva Esperanza, los integrantes platican que decidieron ponerle este nombre porque anteriormente trabajaban en otra microfinanciera y con otras personas desafortunadamente les fue muy mal porque unas personas les quedaron mal en sus pago tuvieron problemas muy fuertes con la asi que cuando escucharon hablar de VFMexico, para ellos fue una esperanza limpiar su historial crediticio y salir adelante en sus negocios. 
 Doña Cristina una mujer ejemplar  muy sonriente trabajadora tiene 42 años de edad está casada con el señor Gabino y tienen tres hijas, una hija pequeña que cursa su educacion primaria es quien aun depende de dicha pareja, Doña Cristina o Cris, como le llaman de cariño, platica que cuando nació su primera niña y fue cuando inició su negocio. Su esposo siempre da había dedicado a al venta de tacos así que con gran esfuerzo esfuerzo ambos reunieron el dinero suficiente y al cabo de un año compraron un pequeño carrito para vender tacos de forma ambulante. Actualmente ya cuentan con dos carros para que ambos puedan trabajar y abarcar dos lugares en el municipio. Todos los días Cris coloca el carrito en el mercado desde las 8 am hasta las 11 pm.  mientras que su esposo esta hasta mas tarde 9 0 10 de la noche, su gran dificultad es la competencia la comunidad donde vive gran parte de la población se dedica a la venta de tacos y en el municipio son mas aun los comerciantes que venden alimento en direntes puntos del municipio sin embargo no le preocupa "Mientras mis negocios nos den para seguir solventando nuestros gastos y pagar el préstamo no me preocupa y seguiremos con los dos negocios" comento muy contenta Doña Cris.
 Su prestamo lo ocupara para comprar dos cerdo, leña, gas e insumos para preparación de tacos, Doña Cris junto con su esposo son quienes sacrifican el animal y preparan las carnitas.
 La meta de Doña Cris es poder hacer crecer sus negocios para seguir apoyando a su hija para que pueda terminar una carrera profesional.
Los integrantes del grupo son Ana Maria quien invierte en tacos, J Carmen en talachas, Ana Maria F. y Maria en zapatos, Juan Luis en ciber, Jose Juan y Franciscoo en tortillas, Maria Elena en Tortilas, Diana Laura en fantasia y Nancy en Blancos.
*La fotografia fue toamada en la casa de Doña Ana Maria, ella es quien tiene el sueter de rayitas,y Doña Cris es quien esta justo detras de ella con el cabello corto*
texts.en:
In a community in the state of Mexico, a group named “La Nueva Esperanza” was formed. The members say that they decided to give themselves this name because previously, they had been working with another micro-finance institution, and with other persons. Unfortunately, it went very badly for them because some people did poorly with their payments, and they had very serious problems. So, when they heard about VF Mexico, they felt hopeful about cleaning up their credit history and moving forward in their businesses.

Doña Cristina is an exemplary woman who is very cheerful and hardworking. She is 42 years old, she is married to Señor Gabino, and they have three daughters. The youngest daughter is studying in primary school and still depends upon them.

Doña Cristina, or “Cris”, as she is affectionately called, says that she started her business when her first daughter was born. Her husband has always worked selling tacos, so they made a great effort, and put together enough money so that after one year they were able to purchase a small cart in order to sell tacos as mobile vendors. Now they have two carts so that they can both work and cover two locations in the city.

Cris stations her little cart in the marketplace from 8:00 AM until 11:00 PM, while her husband is later, until 9:00 or 10:00 PM. Her big difficulty is the competition. In the community in which she lives, a large segment of the population works selling tacos, and there are even more vendors in the city, selling food at different spots. However, she’s not worried. “As long as my businesses are allowing us to keep covering our expenses and paying off the loan, I’m not worried, and we’ll continue with the two businesses”, Doña Cris said happily.

She will use her loan to purchase two pigs, firewood, gas, and supplies for the preparation of tacos. Together, Doña Cris and her husband will slaughter the animals and prepare the pork tacos.

The goal of Doña Cris is to be able to grow her businesses in order to keep supporting her daughter so that she may complete a professional degree program.

The members of the group are: Ana María, who will invest in tacos; J. Carmen, in tires; Ana María F. and María in shoes; Juan Luis, in a cyber café; José Juan, Francisco, and María Elena, in tortillas; Diana Laura in costume jewelry; and Nancy, in linens.

The photograph was taken in Doña Ana María's house. She is the person wearing the striped sweater, and Doña Cris is right behind her, with short hair.

loans.use: to purchase gas, firewood, and two pigs.

loans.name: Shirly

texts.en: Shirly has owned and operated a sari-sari store (convenience store) for 18 years that gives her a monthly income of approximately PHP 8,500. This sufficiently provides for her family's needs. Shirly is supported by her husband who is a construction worker. She has three school-aged children. She is thankful to Paglaum MPC because she accessed financial services as well as life insurance that she really enjoys. Recently, she requested a loan of PHP 25,000 to purchase galvanized iron sheets, sticks, plywood, nails and other items. She hopes to live comfortably with her family in a decent house.

loans.use: to purchase galvanized iron sheets, sticks, plywood, nails and other items

loans.name: Avenida 2 Group

texts.es:
La represa de la comunidad es el mayor atractivo turístico de la comunidad, ver partir a los pescadores en sus lanchas de motor o chalupas a remos  a pescar para posteriormente vender las mojarras de manera ambulante, en la cooperativa o en las palapas que están a la orilla de la represa donde las colocan en pequeños estanques y cuando el comensal llega le brindan mojarras frescas.

En una de las colonias se formó un grupo de 6 personas quienes solicitaron un préstamo a Visión F México para acrecentar sus actividades, el grupo lleva por nombre A venida 2 pues es la avenida donde se encuentra el punto de reunión del grupo, ellos son:

Silvestre - Zapatos
María, Fabiola, Lorena, Mayra – Ropa 
Zoila - Refrescos
