The demand for poultry products in the Siongiroi area is very high and through the loan she will be able to satisfy the demand. Other than profits from poultry farming, she will also benefit from poultry manure, hence saving money that would have been used in purchasing fertilizers.

The additional income from this expansion will permanently change her life and improve her living conditions. Her goal is to continue working to achieve her dream of paying for her children's education, and later on, purchasing more land for farming.

loans.use: To buy additional poultry.

loans.name: Felix Antonio

texts.es:
Felix es un hombre de 39 años de edad, viudo, sin hijos, y su negocio es la reparación de automóviles.
Él es independiente, emprendedor, constante, paciente, responsable y muy trabajador. Su negocio lo realiza en la zona de ‘Pampahasi’ caracterizada por encontrarse sobre una ladera muy empinada donde existen deslizamientos de tierra, y muchos de los cuales tienen un alto costo humano. De clima frio y seco con una temperatura que varía durante el día entre 1-12 grados centígrados.
Felix es de tez morena, ojos pardos, cabello negro corto, baja estatura, complexión física delgada, su lengua materna es el Aymará que habla en familia y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza. Su vida la comparte con sus padres que trabajan independientemente, viven en una casa propia construido de ladrillo y cemento con techo de calamina y piso de madera que cuenta con agua potable, energía eléctrica y alcantarillado. Su negocio es la mecánica automotriz, el cual realiza en su taller propio ubicado en cercanías de su casa, se ocupa de arreglar; motores, correas de distribución, elementos de transmisión, etc, “el automóvil tiene alrededor de 7000 piezas diferentes; Algunas son para hacerlo más cómodo, darle mejor aspecto y ofrecer seguridad, pero la mayoría son para hacerlo funcionar…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que cuanta con clientes continuos, la desventaja es la falta de capital para la compra de una máquina compresora. Su sueño es tener un taller mecánico completo que brinde todos los servicios de mantenimiento, él desea realizar la compra de una máquina compresora para hinchar llantas. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 10 años que se dedica a esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Felix solicita un préstamo para la compra de una máquina compresora para hinchar llantas.
texts.en:
Felix is a 39-year-old widowed man without children. His business is repairing automobiles.

He is independent, entrepreneurial, constant, patient, responsible and very hardworking.

His business is in the Pampahasi area, known for its location on a steep slope where there are landslides, many of which have a high human cost. It has cold, dry weather with temperatures that vary between 1-12 degrees Celsius during the day.

Felix has a dark complexion, brown eyes, short black hair, a short stature and a skinny physique. His native language is Aymara, which he speaks with his family, and he speaks Spanish for general culture and the business he goes.

He shares his life with his parents, who work independently and live in their own house made of brick and cement with a tin roof and wood floor. It has potable water, electricity and sewage.

He works as an auto mechanic in his own workshop located near his home. He spends his time fixing motors, timing belts, transmission elements, etc.

"A car has about 7,000 different pieces. Some are to make it more comfortable, give it a better appearance or provide security, but most are to make it run," he says.

An advantage of his business is that he has continuous clients, but a disadvantage is the lack of capital to buy a compressor machine. His dream is to have a complete mechanical workshop that provides all maintenance services.

He wants to buy a compressor machine to inflate tires. He is in the first loan sequence with the institution and has been in his line of work for 10 years. Because of these goals, Felix is seeking a loan to buy a compressor machine to inflate tires.

loans.use: to buy a compressor machine for inflating tires.

loans.name: Estrella De Belen Group

texts.es:
Maria es una mujer de 22 años de edad, vive con su pareja, tiene un hijo recién nacido de 8 meses, y su negocio es la venta de cena.
Ella es buena madre, optimista, alegre, feliz, espontanea, responsable y muy trabajadora. Su negocio lo realiza en la zona ‘plan 3000’ que es una de las ciudades que más ha crecido y continua creciendo debido a la migración del país, en donde se destacan grandes emprendimientos comerciales y habitacionales así como de servicios de salud, educación y terciarios.  De clima cálido subtropical, con una temperatura que ronda entre los 21-35 grados centígrados.
Maria es de tez trigueña, ojos pardos, cabello negro lacio largo lo usa amarrado por detrás, baja estatura, complexión física delgada, su lengua materna es el Guaraní que habla en familia y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza (de pie al centro, envuelta en una frazada amarilla). Su vida la comparte con su pareja que se dedica a la construcción y con su hijo que esta recién nacido, viven en un cuarto alquilado construido de madera con techo de calamina y piso de ladrillo que cuenta con agua potable, energía eléctrica y alcantarillado. la necesidad por pagar los gastos posnatales de su recién nacido, la llevaron a formar una banca de personas con negocio como; artesanía en cerámica, elaboración de sombreros de sao, confección de tejidos, panadería, venta de flores, carnicería y venta de queso, para solicitar un préstamo y mejorar sus negocios. Su negocio es la venta de cena, ella se dedica a comprar alimentos durante el día para cocinarlos y venderlos en la noche para la hora de la cena, las comidas mayormente demandadas son; el majao (carne deshidratada, arroz, huevo frito y plátano frito), locro (sopa de carne deshidratada, carne cortada en pedacitos, yuca y huevo), Sopa de Remojado (sopa de huesos), y otras, “el menú es relativamente variado, es decir, existen bastantes opciones diferentes, pero no es un mar de comidas, El furor de las comidas son las ensaladas con diferentes acompañamientos según el tipo de cocina…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que cuenta con ventas diarias, la desventaja es la falta de capital para la compra de un carrito hamburguesero para ofrecer la comida de hamburguesas. Su sueño es consolidar sus negocios, ella desea realizar la compra de un carrito hamburguesero para ofrecer hamburguesas de forma ambulante en el día. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 2 años que se dedica a esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Maria solicita un préstamo para la compra de un carrito hamburguesero para contar con una segunda actividad y pagar los gastos de su recién nacido.
texts.en:
Maria is a 22 year old woman, she lives with her partner and has a new born baby, aged 8 months. She sells dinner. She is a good mother, who is optimistic, happy, cheerful, spontaneous, responsible and very hard working.

Her business is situated in the 'Plan 3000' zone which is one of the cities which has experience the most growth, and is continuing to grow due to migration within the country, and in which great commercial and housing business ventures stand out, as well as in the health, education and service sectors. There is a hot, sub-tropical climate, with a temperature ranging from 21-35 degrees centigrade.

Maria has a dark complexion, brown eyes and long, straight black hair which she wears tied back, and is short and slender. Her maternal language is Guaraní which they speak within the family, but she also speaks Spanish due to the general culture and for her work (she is standing in the center, wrapped in a yellow blanket). She lives with her partner, who works in construction, and with her new born child. They live in a rented room, made from wood with a corrugated iron roof and brick flooring, which has running water, electricity and a sewage system.

The need to pay for the costs of having a new born baby led her to set up a communal bank with people running businesses such as: ceramic handicrafts, sao hat making, knitting, a bakery, flower sales, a butcher, and cheese sales, in order to request a loan to improve their respective businesses.

Her business is in dinner sales, she buys foods during the day to cook and sell in the evenings at dinner time. The most frequently requested meals are: majao (dried meat, rice, fried egg and fried banana), locro (stew with dried meat, chopped meat, cassava and egg) Sopa de Remojado (soup made from bones) and other things. "The menu is relatively varied, there are several different options but it is not a whole ocean of foods. Much of the food is salads with different accompaniments, according to the type of food" she says.

The advantage of her business is that she sells every day, the disadvantage is that she doesn't have the funds to buy a hamburger cart to offer hamburger sales. Her dream is to strengthen her business, she wishes to buy a hamburger cart so that she can sell hamburgers on the street during the day. This is the first loan with the institution in the two years that she has been doing this job.

This is why Maria is requesting a loan to buy a hamburger cart, to set up a second job and to pay the costs of her new born baby.

loans.use: to buy a hamburger cart, to set up a second job and to pay the costs of her new born baby.

loans.name: Rocio

texts.es:
Rocio es una mujer de 22 años de edad, vive con su pareja, tiene un hijo de 2 años, y su negocio es la venta de verduras. 
Ella es buena madre, optimista, generosa, amable, responsable y muy trabajadora. Su negocio lo realiza en la localidad ‘El torno’ localizada a 32 kilómetros de la ciudad, considerado como el centro poblado más importante con un área urbana consolidada y otros barrios en proceso de consolidación, la carretera asfaltada se convierte en avenida principal que une a las poblaciones aledañas. De clima cálido subtropical, con una temperatura que ronda entre los 21-35 grados centígrados.
Rocio es de tez morena, ojos pardos, cabello negro largo lo usa trenzado, baja estatura, complexión física robusta, su forma de vestir es tradicional (sombrero, manta y pollera), su lengua materna es el Guaraní que habla en familia y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza. Su vida la comparte con su pareja que trabaja en construcción y con su hijo que aún no se encuentra en edad escolar, viven en un cuarto propio construido de madera con techo de calamina y piso de tierra que cuenta con agua de pozo extraída mediante bomba, energía eléctrica y no cuenta con alcantarillado. Su negocio es la venta de verduras, como; yuca, papa, tomate, zanahoria, zapallo, repollo y otras, “mi negocio rota a diario, las verduras que no se venden porque se marchitan, las juntamos y la vendemos como comida para el ganado…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que se vende toda su mercadería por completo, la desventaja es la falta de capital para la refacción del techo de su puesto de venta, para que no filtre agua y los alimentos se conserven correctamente. Su sueño es mejorar los ingresos de su negocio, ella desea realizar la refacción del techo de su puesto de venta, para que no filtre agua y los alimentos se conserven correctamente. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 2 años que se dedica a esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Rocio solicita un préstamo para la refacción del techo de su puesto de venta, para que no filtre agua y los alimentos se conserven correctamente.
texts.en:
Rocio is a 22-year-old woman who lives with her domestic partner and has a two-year-old child. Her occupation is selling vegetables. Rocio is a good mother, optimistic, generous, kind, responsible and very hard-working.

Her business is located in an area called "El Torno", about 32 kilometers from the city which is considered the most important center of population with a consolidated urban area and other neighborhoods in the process of consolidation. The paved road acts as a "main street" uniting the surrounding neighborhoods. It has a warm subtropical climate, with temperatures that range from 21 to 35 degrees centigrade (70 - 95 F). Rocio has a dark complexion, brown eyes, long black hair that she wears braided, and is short and stocky. She wears traditional clothing (hat, shawl and pollera (typical skirt). Her native language is Guarani which she speaks at home, but she speaks Spanish in general and at her business.

She shares her life with her domestic partner who is a construction worker, and with her son who is not yet of school age. They live in their own room constructed of wood with a metal roof and an earthen floor. It has pumped well water, electricity, but no sewerage.

Her occupation is selling vegetables such as yucca, potatoes, tomatoes, carrots, squash, cabbage and others. "My business turns over daily; we package up the unsold, withered vegetables and sell it as food for the cattle..." she states. The advantage of her business is that she sells all of her merchandise completely, and the disadvantage is the lack of funds to repair the roof of her stand to keep out the rain and to protect the food correctly.

Her dream is to increase her income from her business. This is the first loan sequence with the institution in the two years she has been running her vegetable stand. These are the reasons why Rocio is asking for a loan - to repair the roof of her vegetable stand to keep out the water and to protect the food.

loans.use: to repair the roof of her stand to keep out the rain and better preserve the food.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Hello lenders. Meet Joan, a very industrious, honest, and hardworking woman who hails from the Siongiroi area of Kenya, an area that is near the famous Rift valley escarpment. She is 32 years of age and has been farming for the past eight years.

Through those years, she has gathered so much experience and is considered among the best farmers in her village. She has been practicing mixed farming and her primary source of income has been milk, eggs, crops, and some small businesses that she does so that she can make ends meet (posho mill).

Joan is very passionate about farming and she loves cultivating her farm. That is why every day she wakes up very early to go to her farm to plough. Although Joan makes profits through farming, she is not comfortable and has always wanted to increase her income through the selling of cereals. That is why she is seeking a loan to buy cereals. The Siongiroi area is one of the regions that is populated and has a high demand for cereals. That means that Joan will make more profits and be able to satisfy the demand that is there.

Accessing funds has been a challenge for Joan, but she feels relieved, because Juhudi Kilimo is partnering with Kiva lenders to help aspiring women farmers like her turn their farming dreams into reality through training and loan financing. Joan believes that this loan will be of much help and she will be able to satisfy the demand that is there for cereals.

She believes that the extra income will allow permanent change to her life and increase her business. Increased profits will allow Joan to repay the loan, and secure the future of her school going children. Lenders, if there is someone you should invest in, then it is Joan.

loans.use: to purchase cereals to sell.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Hello, world! Meet Ruth, a very hardworking mother who is 35 years of age. She is a small holder farmer from Kanyekiini, a remote village in the fertile Nkubu area of Kenya.

This charming mother of two has been engaged in mixed farming for the past five years. She commands a lot of respect from fellow farmers in her village. Her main source of income has been eggs, milk, and a variety of food crops that she plants. Taking care of her farm is an activity she finds very enjoyable.

Ruth has good knowledge of the market and has been taking advantage of the ready market. However, the demand of banana is so high. Being a visionary woman, she has always wanted to buy seeds for banana farming. She is seeking a loan to buy seeds for banana farming.

Accessing financial services for women is very difficult, but through institutions such as Kiva, enterprising women like Ruth will achieve their dreams and goals. Ruth believes that the key to increased banana production is proper taking care of her farm.

Nkubu area has a ready market for bananas and through this loan she will be able to satisfy the demand that is there, and hence improve her income. The increased income will be used to improve her living conditions and to repay the loan.

loans.use: to buy seeds for banana farming.

loans.name: Los Aliados Group

texts.es:
Rosmery continúa con su actividad de venta de productos de primera necesidad en su tienda de barrio. El crédito anterior lo invirtió en la compra de alimentos y productos de primera necesidad como; azúcar, fideo, arroz, pan, papel higiénico, gaseosas, detergentes, etc. Para abastecer su negocio. El pago de sus cuotas fue puntual porque no tuvo problemas (la primera de la izquierda, sostiene a su bebe en brazos). En esta oportunidad reunió a la banca de personas para solicitar otro crédito para continuar mejorando sus negocios, las actividades de los integrantes son; venta de ropa de segunda mano, artesanía en cuero, venta de queso, panadería, confección de tejidos, venta de comida y venta de refrescos. Su negocio es la tienda de barrio; ella atiende una tienda de barrio en su mismo domicilio dónde vende alimentos y artículos de primera necesidad como; refrescos, pan, azúcar, golosinas, etc, “gracias a mi negocio puedo cuidar a mis hijos y trabajar…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que las ventas son a diario, la desventaja es la falta de capital para abastecer y reponer la tienda de abarrotes. Su sueño es ampliar su negocio para mejorar sus ventas y pagar los gastos de sus hijos, ella desea realiza la compra de abarrotes en general para surtir su tienda y cumplir con los gastos de sus hijos. Esta es la 2 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 1 año que realiza esta actividad. 
Es por esos motivos que Rosmery solicita un préstamo para la compra de abarrotes en general para surtir su tienda y cumplir con los gastos de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Rosmery continues selling staple goods at her neighborhood store. With the previous loan, she bought food and staple goods such as sugar, pasta, rice, bread, toilet paper, soft drinks, detergent, etc., to stock her business. She payed her installment payments on time because she didn't have any problems. In the photo, Rosmery is the first one on the left, holding a baby in her arms. On this occasion, the bank gathered people together so they could request another loan in order to continue improving their businesses.

The members' activities are: selling secondhand clothes, leather craftsmanship, selling cheese, a bakery, weaving, selling food, and selling soft drinks. Rosmery runs a neighborhood store. The store is located at her home and she sells food and staple goods, such as soft drinks, bread, sugar, sweets, etc. "Thanks to my business, I can take care of my children and work," she says. The advantage her business is that sales are made daily. The disadvantage is the lack of funds to stock and replenish her store.

Rosmery's dream is to expand her store in order to increase her sales and pay for her children's expenses. She wants to buy groceries to stock her store and to pay for her children's expenses. This is her 2nd loan cycle with the institution in the year that she's had her business. Because of these reasons, Rosmery is requesting a loan to buy groceries to stock her business and pay for her children's expenses.

loans.use: to buy groceries to stock her store and to pay for her children's expenses.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
A hardworking woman, honest, humble and full of life--this how to describe Nelly. She is a rural farmer in Singiroi, Kenya, an area known for having bad terrain and a lack of proper infrastructure. She is blessed with a lovely family and has been practicing mixed farming for the past five years. On her farm, she grows maize and she raises a dairy cow and poultry. She sells milk, eggs, and maize. To meet her expenses and provide the best for her family, she often engages in small personal businesses to make extra money. However, farming gives her a great sense of satisfaction, despite meager earnings. Nelly says, "I enjoy it most when I see customers come back for my products because it shows me that I am meeting their needs!" 

Her biggest challenge is drought. The long dry season can lead to crop failures and poor yields. For a farmer, this means business losses and lack of food for the family. Because of this challenge, Nelly formed a group and joined Juhudi Kilimo, a microfinance organization that supports small rural farmers. She acquired a dairy cow. The cow produces milk daily, which Nelly sells to a co-operative. "The money from the milk comes regularly and is not very affected by sudden changes in weather if you have stored feed," says Nelly. The money Nelly got from selling the milk was adequate to repay the loan. 

Today, Nelly is seeking a new loan to buy another dairy cow because she is planning to become a full-fledged dairy farmer. Her future plan is to construct a zero-grazing unit. That way, she can use the grazing field to plant fodder and prepare silage. With this loan, Nelly is going to grow into a very successful dairy farmer. All she wants is for her family to enjoy the abundance of life, good health and good livelihood. Her only dream is to continue growing her business and in the future to leave it to her children.

Nelly patiently waits for your kindness.

loans.use: To buy a quality breed of dairy cow

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Meet an amazing, honest and charming woman by the name of Grace. She is a small-holder farmer based in Lolminingai village in the Nandi hills, Kenya. Grace has been practicing livestock farming for seven years .She has raised two cows on the farm. Grace is seeking a loan to restock her cereals business. She plans to purchase and transport cereals in bulk to far markets where she will sell at prices high enough to cover all the expenses incurred while gaining a profit. Grace is confident that she will be able to repay the loan in time because she is hard working and financially disciplined. Returns from the investment will change her life as she will use the additional income to raise her family's living standards.
Grace just needs a little help that she can get from you; a loan that may change her life.

loans.use: to purchase cereals

loans.name: Irine

texts.en:
Always there is a reason to smile, but today Irine has a big reason, and it is that she is only one step away from being able to start her own cereal selling business, thanks to Juhudi Kilimo and the Kiva lenders.

Irine is an amazing woman who is a smallholder farmer based in Lolminingai village in the Nandi Hills, Kenya. She is married to her handsome hubby, James, with whom she has been together for almost a decade. She has two children who commute to school from home every school-day. Irine has been practicing livestock farming for ten years to help her husband cover family expenses. She has managed to raise two cows and ten poultry on the farm.

Irine is seeking a loan to stock her cereals business. She plans to use the money to purchase and transport cereals in bulk to far markets, where she will sell at prices high enough to cater for all the expenses incurred plus profit. Irine is confident that she will be able to repay the loan in time because she is hard-working and financially disciplined.

Returns from the investment will change her life, as she will use the additional income to raise her family's living standards and pay for her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase cereals

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Nearly all the people in the Nandi Hills area are farmers and Cecilia is one of them. Cecilia is a mixed farmer based in Koilot, a remote village in the Nandi Hills area of Kenya. Cecilia is a proud mother of four lovely, school-going children, whom she truly loves and greatly adores. Cecilia describes her upbringing as challenging, so she is doing everything in her power to provide a good foundation for her children and to help secure their future.

Cecilia is seeking a loan to purchase farm inputs. With the KES 20,000 (Kenya shillings) loan, she is going to pay for a truckload of manure and also pay for seedlings.

Cecilia has been farming for nearly one decade. She is going to use your loan investment and the years of experience she has gathered, to make this expansion a success. Money gathered from this investment will enable Cecilia to contribute to her family's general expenses, her children's education, and medical needs.

loans.use: to buy manure and seedlings for her farm.

loans.name: Penina

texts.en:
Hello Kiva lenders! Meet Penina, a young farmer from Maraa, a remote village in Nkubu, Kenya, who has defied the common thinking about most Kenyans that agriculture is for the older generation.

Penina is happily married and, together with her husband, blessed with a lovely family. Her primary sources of income are dairy farming, crop farming, and some personal business. Penina practices agriculture with a difference, employing youthful energy, enthusiasm, and knowledge from the many agricultural trainings she has been attending to broaden her skills.

Although she earns handsome profits from farming, she faces one big challenge and that is high prices in fertilizers, seedlings, and inputs, and this is a result of the monopoly that is enjoyed by the only agro vet shop in her area. She is requesting a loan to start an agro vet shop.

The Maraa area has only one agro dealer who is catering for thousands of smallholder farmers who solely depend on him for agricultural inputs. The agro dealer has been making a killing from farmers by charging them extra amounts since he is the only agro dealer and enjoys monopoly.

Penina wants to change this and seize the business opportunity. Through your loan, she will start an agro vet shop and tap into the potential agricultural market. Penina will also help the smallholder farmers in her area who for a long time have been having a serious problem accessing affordable farm inputs.

Through increased income from the loan, she will improve her living conditions and her future plans are to open more agro shops so that she can make her services easily available. She patiently waits for your kindness.

loans.use: to start an agro vet shop

loans.name: Binkan Group

texts.fr: Boureima  est celui qui tient la corne du bélier dans la photo.C’est un éleveur d’ovin de nationalité Malienne, âge de 49 ans, marié et père de 6 enfants dont 2 garçons e sont  scolarisés. Il exerce cette activité d’élevage d’ovin depuis 10 ans.Il achète ses bétails  dans leur village, il  les élève et les revend avec bénéfice après quelques mois dans divers villages. Le prêt lui permettra de développer son activité, et le revenu sera investi pour prendre quelques besoins familiaux comme l’habillement et les frais scolaires de ses enfants. Son principal rêve est de construire pour ses enfants.
texts.en:
Boureima is holding the ram’s horn in the photo. He is a Malian ovine farmer. He is 49 years old, married, and the father of six children—including two boys—who are in school.

He has been running his ovine farming business for 10 years. He purchases livestock in his village, raises them and after a few months resells them for profit in a variety of villages.

The loan will allow him to grow his business, and the profit will be used for family expenses such as clothing and schooling fees for his children. His main goal is to build up the business for his children.

loans.use: to purchase livestock for resale.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Farming has always played a core role in Kenya and in East Africa as a whole. Dairy farming is done mainly on a small scale for survival. Lydia has kept dairy animals for five years on her farm in the Nandi Hills area of Kenya. Since Lydia had children, her personal and financial obligations have skyrocketed. She has different ways to make money, but keeps coming up short.

Lydia decided the best way to grow economically was to improve her farm's productivity. To increase milk production, she could either buy more cows or replace the existing cows with more productive breeds. The latter makes more economic sense. Traditional breeds are well-adjusted to the environmental conditions and disease resistant, but their milk production is very low. Cross-breeds and Friesians are more productive and can survive in the same environment as the traditional breeds, but they come at a price.

Lydia is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to purchase a productive dairy cow that will bring her more income. She will use the additional income to pay for her children's education and to meet family expenses. Her future plan is to keep growing her income-generating asset base.

loans.use: To buy a quality breed of dairy cow

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Kenya’s farmers are generally poor and small-scale farmers who cannot afford to have access to credit facilities. Hello, lenders! Meet Sophia, a youthful 28-year-old farmer who is very kind, loving, and charming. She is based in Nyaki, a remote village in the Nkubu area of Kenya. For the past five years, she has been involved in mixed farming on her small piece of land. Her major sources of income are egg-selling, crops, and some personal business she engages in to make ends meet.

Sophia is a farmer who truly needs help. At 28 years old, she has the enormous responsibility of taking care of her family and siblings. The situation is very difficult because Sophia does not have a job. Sophia passionately loves poultry farming, and when asked what is most enjoyable about poultry farming, her response was “feeding my poultry.” She sells eggs and poultry products to her neighbors and at the local market, and, because of high quality eggs, customers have been streaming into her compound and the demand has been overwhelming.

To be able to meet the demand, Sophia is requesting a loan to buy additional poultry. Through the loan she will buy quality breeds of poultry that have high productivity and hence satisfy the demand that is there. The increased income level will be used in improving her living conditions, and she plans on expanding her business to other towns.

Other than increased profits, she will also benefit from poultry manure which will be used in her vegetable garden to increase productivity. Increased profits will make Sophia's business flourish and hence provide a secure and solid education to her family. You can help this woman improve her business, provide for her family, and educate her siblings. Help her out!

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna, 37, is a smallholder dairy farmer from Sangurer village based in the remote area of Kapsowar, Kenya. She does mixed farming and also she does some side hustle business (a sewing business).

Edna is hardworking and determined to make it in the world of farming. The land she owns is big enough to support more than just dairy animals. She is planning to make use of the available space to start growing food crops.

Starting a horticultural farm is very costly, especially for smallholder rural farmers. Besides securing land space, a farmer needs to invest in intensive labour, farm tools, and farm inputs. The farmer will also have to construct a store/granary for his/her produce.

Edna is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to buy seeds and venture into horticulture. With your loan investment into her business, Edna will be having an alternative source of income besides dairy in the near future. This will not only make her family better off but also open new possibilities for her to diversify further in future.

loans.use: To venture into horticulture farming

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys is the mother of two lovely children and is a very hard-working woman. She is based in Chepkunyuk, a remote village in the Nandi hills, an area with fertile soil famous for dairy farming. The region's staple food is mursik, a mouthwatering delicacy prepared from milk. Gladys has been practicing mixed farming for the past 10 years. Selling eggs and milk has earned her a decent income. She also engages in another business to make ends meet. Gladys passionately loves dairy farming, and taking care of her cows gives her great joy. She wakes up every morning to milk her cows. While this humble mom has been making a profit by selling milk to her neighbors and the local market, she is faced with the challenge of meeting the demand. She is known for having the best quality milk. Through word of mouth, customers have been flocking to her farm for milk. Gladys is seeking a loan to buy a quality dairy cow that will produce milk that is high in nutrients and will be able to satisfy the demand. With this loan, she will buy a dairy cow that will produce between 10 and 20 liters of milk a day. This will help fully satisfy the demand. Through Kiva Field Partner Juhudi Kilimo, she attended training sessions and was taught financial management skills. This will help her save more money, repay the loan fully, and improve her living conditions. You can help Gladys to accomplish all these dreams with a loan, so do it now and get her closer to her goals.

loans.use: To buy another quality dairy cow

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica, at the age of 30, is a charismatic and helpful woman who works in her own small farm that she began due to the need to generate income to support her family.

In spite of all the obstacles, she had the strength and the determination to pick herself up and keep on going, and thanks to this she's been doing farming for the past seven years. She works every day for ten hours by herself.

Veronica is seeking a loan to construct a dairy shed. This will provide shelter for her favorite animal. The thing she enjoys most about dairy farming is selling milk. However, in order for a dairy cow to be more productive, the farmer needs to be good at dairy management.

Your loan will help Veronica construct a cowshed that will help very much with dairy management. The shelter will enable her to prepare feed rations and feed the cow. The shed will also ensure the cow is always in a clean and hygienic environment.

Your loan will bring untold benefits to Veronica. She is projecting a significant increase in milk production. The extra money will go to loan repayment and her children’s education. Her dream is for her children to live a better life with fulfilled basic needs. Help her out!

loans.use: to construct a modern dairy cowshed

loans.name: Tereza

texts.en: With children to raise, water to fetch, and food to cook, Tereza creates time to tend to her farm. Every day she wakes up at 5 o’clock in the morning to start her day. Tereza is a small-holder farmer from Nandihills area of Kenya. She is a mother of two. Like many farmers in the region, she has a dairy cow. Nandihills has a thriving market for dairy products. Tereza has sustained herself through dairy farming for seven years now. She enjoys the farming lifestyle. She has a connection with farm animals that goes so deep that she even names each of them. She has aspirations of expanding her dairy farm, but due to financial constraints, she has been unable to do so until now. From Kiva lenders, Tereza is borrowing KES 46,575 to purchase a high yielding dairy cow. This cow will boost milk production in the farm. As a result, she will have more quantity for both consumption and sales. With the money from the additional sales, she will be able to service her loan on time. With increased income from the loan, Tereza plans  to settle the high farming cost of production. Many farmers compromise quality because of the high cost of inputs. However, with increased income, Tereza will not take such measures. In the long run, her family will realize an improved standard of living.

loans.use: To grow her horticulture business

loans.name: Cruzencia

texts.en: Cruzencia is ambitious, admirable, and a hard-worker who wants to triumph. She wants to leave her mark on the world. At 25 years old, she is independent and runs her own mixed farming business. She is very pragmatic and considers herself more hard working than others. Cruzencia owns a 0.7 acre piece of land that she uses to grow maize and keep dairy animals. She has also planted 200 trees on it for aesthetic appearance and environmental health. The land provides her with not only capital for her business but also a home for her family. She is blessed to have two children and a husband she has stayed married to for five years. Cruzencia is seeking a loan to purchase cereals. The cereals she is seeking serve to replenish stock for her food and her business. The demand for cereals in the market, only a few kilometers from Cruzencia's home, is up. Farmers in the area are rushing to grow more cereal crops. By placing herself in a position of supplying cereal seeds and still being a cereal farmer, she gets to enjoy profits from selling inputs and crop harvests. Your loan will directly elevate Cruzencia’s livelihood. She strives to give her children a better life than the tough upbringing she grew up in.

loans.use: to buy cereal seeds

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is from Nandihills, Kenya, with a fierce entrepreneurial spirit. Speaking with her it becomes obvious that she is a very hard-working and helpful woman, and that everything she does is for her family's benefit and well-being. She lives in a humble home along with her husband and their five children. Nandi Hills has good weather patterns that favor crop and dairy farming. Eunice enjoys farming, which she has been doing on her small piece of land for the past five years. Through all those years, she has gained much experience and is one of the most respected farmers in her village. Because of the immense knowledge that she has of dairy farming, Eunice offers extension services to other farmers who are new to the business. Being a caring and loving mother, Eunice has been able to take care of her family and support them through the profits she has earned from farming. Although Eunice reaps much profit from farming, one challenge that she is facing that is dragging her down and preventing her from reaching her goal is lack of enough land to farm. For this reason, Eunice is seeking a loan of KES 45,000 to buy a piece of land and expand her farming activities. Having so much experience in farming, Eunice is sure that she will make good use of the land and double her profit levels. Through the profits, she would be able to repay the loan and improve her living conditions. Eunice is sure that if you invest in her, she will be able to realize her dream of having a good quality life and securing her children's future. Eunice has gone through the repayment schedule and amount and is comfortable with the plan. 
Support the project of an enterprising Kenyan woman!

loans.use: To buy land

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.es:
Cecilia, agradece el apoyo que la institución le ha brindado para que su negocio de venta de pupusas sea más grande, tiene clientes nuevos y satisfechos, su familia se conserva con los mismos miembros pero viven en óptimas condiciones.
Ha decidido solicitar un nuevo crédito para comprar quesillo, aceite, harina, maíz, leña y aderezos, básicamente adquirirá la materia prima para preparar la venta de pupusas, su prioridad es mantener las ventas y satisfacer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Cecilia is grateful for the support that the institution has given her so that she could expand her pupusa business. She has new, satisfied customers. Her family is the same as before but they now live in optimal conditions.

Cecilia has decided to apply for a new loan to buy cheese, oil, flour, corn, wood and garnishes - all the materials she needs to prepare and sell pupusas. Her priority is to maintain her level of sales and to satisfy her customers.

loans.use: purchase corn, dressings, oil, cheese, beverages, pork rinds, etc. to make her pupusas.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is a woman with all the spirit for work, who resides in a remote village in the Nkubu area of Kenya. For the past five years, Regina has been involved in mixed farming. Her primary sources of income have been planting different varieties of crops and some personal business she engages in to earn additional income. Regina has been able to provide nutritious food for her family.

She passionately loves dairy farming. Villagers have nicknamed her Mrs. Cow. Regina sells milk to her neighbors and to the local market, but her cows have started to produce low quantities of milk because they are sick because they lack a proper dairy unit where they can stay. For this reason, she is requesting a loan to build a modern dairy unit.

Through the loan she will be able to build a good place where her cows can relax and also where they will least be affected by harsh weather conditions such as rain and sunlight. A proper dairy unit also provides a good place to feed your cow. This proper dairy unit will immediately translate to increased milk production and increased income levels.

Profits from selling milk will be used to repay the loan. The extra income will be used to increase her business enterprise. Regina is very visionary, and she intends to start adding value to her milk business. All that she patiently waits for is your kindness.

loans.use: To build a modern dairy unit

loans.name: Felista

texts.en:
Regardless of the great impact that agriculture has on the Kenyan economy, micro-finance institutions (M.F.I.'s) view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition. Juhudi Kilimo is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Kenyan farmers.

Meet Felista, an ever-smiling, hardworking, and honest mother who is 59 years of age. She hails from the Chuka area of Kenya. She is the proud mother of three lovely children. She loves and treasures her children and will go the extra mile to make sure that they are comfortable.

Felista’s primary source of income has been selling milk, crop farming, and poultry farming. Through these ventures she has been able to earn a decent income. She is a very determined and dedicated farmer who has been farming for 35 years, and throughout, she has never regretted going into farming.

Although this humble mum has been making profits, not everything has been “a bed of roses." She faces financial challenges, and because the Chuka area has proven a ready market for cereals, she is kindly seeking a loan to buy cereals for re-sale and thus improve her income.

Felista’s upbringing was challenging, and she has faced many economic problems. Still, this ever-smiling mum has been making great improvements, and she believes that through your loan she will be able to realize her goal of improving her living conditions and transforming her life.

Through Juhudi Kilimo, Felista has received training and she has proven to be honest and disciplined with finances. She intends to fully repay the loan with the profits from her business. Felista is quite visionary and--with her accumulated profits--hopes she will be able to open a large cereal-selling shop that will boost her income and turn her life around.

loans.use: To buy cereals for re-sale.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Hello, Kiva Lenders! Meet Emily, from Nandi Hills, Kenya, a woman from a community not known for farming, but she is earning a living through agriculture. She is happily married and, together with her husband, is blessed with three lovely children.

For the past 20 years, Emily has been practicing mixed farming and, because of the experience she has, she commands a lot of respect from fellow farmers and she is regarded as a mentor. Money from milk, eggs, and crop farming have allowed her to earn a decent income. To make extra coin, Emily engages in small, personal business.

Emily passionately loves dairy farming and an animal on her farm has been given the name of “Koriot.” Milking and feeding Koriot (the name of her cow) makes her very proud. Through milk selling, she has had quite good returns and the demand for milk has been expanding. Demand has been overwhelming and she needs an extra breed of cow to fully satisfy the demand.

Emily is requesting a loan to buy a quality dairy cow. Emily does not intend to buy just an ordinary cow, she wants to buy a distinct breed that is easy to manage and has a natural ability to produce rich, creamy milk. The dairy cow will be producing between 15-20 liters of milk a day.

The increased milk production will translate into more income and Emily will be able to improve her living conditions and secure the future of her school-going children. This loan will permanently change Emily's living standards and there is no doubt that you can find rewarding employment in dairy farming.

loans.use: To buy a quality dairy cow

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is a hardworking woman. She is 17 years old and lives in the town of Zanna in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 5 years, Aisha has been working hard to manage her clothing business. 

To help expand her business, Aisha has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes and will help Aisha generate greater profits and provide for her family's basic needs. Aisha hopes that in the future she will be able to take a class in journalism.

Aisha is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: buy more clothes

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more shirts and dresses to sell.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan is a hard working woman. Joan is 21 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past 3 years, Joan has been working hard to manage her Stationary shop, which operates a stationary business. 

To help expand her business, Joan has requested a loan of 1,250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stationary items, and will help Joan to generate greater profits and improve family welfare. Joan hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the business. 

Joan is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: uy more stationary items

loans.name: Control Solidarity Group

texts.en:
Aminata is a 32-year-old businesswoman and a member of Control Solidarity Group. Control Solidarity Group has four members; all are women.  Aminata sells cooking ingredients like rice, magi, onions, cooking oil, tomato paste, etc. to many households. 

Aminata has been in this grocery business for the past 5 years. She opens her business six days a week from 8 AM to 6 PM.

Aminata established her business to help support her children in school. She pays school fees, buys learning material, and provides food from the profit she gets from her business. Aminata is in the left of the picture.

Aminata and her group members need a loan totaling 4,000,000 SLL, of which she is entitled to 1,000,000 SLL, which she will use to buy one rubber oil, one bag of onions, five bags of salt, five cartons of tomato paste, etc. for her business.

She hopes that this loan will help her generate more profit to support her family. Aminata is married and has two children with the ages of 21 and 8; both are going to school.

In the future, Aminata plans to save more money to provide for her children’s university educations. She believes educating her children to university level will better the lives of her family.

Aminata and the rest of the group members will be very appreciative to anyone that can help.

loans.use: to buy one rubber oil, one bag of onions, five bags of salt, five cartons of tomato paste, etc

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a humble mother who wakes up every morning at 5 o’clock to work on her farm. She is fully dedicated to her farm work and thinks only of progressing. Lucy resides in the Nkubu area of Kenya which is a remote town with harsh living conditions because of the bad terrain in the region. She is happily married and, together with her husband, has a lovely family. Lucy’s primary sources of income are milk and some personal business she engages in to make ends meet. Lucy has managed to take care of her family with her income from selling different varieties of food crops. The Nkubu area has conditions that favor crop farming.

Lucy has always wanted to start banana farming but the lack of capital has prevented her. She is seeking a loan to buy seeds and start banana farming. With this loan she will be able to harvest more bananas and hence satisfy the ready market in her region. Demand for bananas in the Nkubu area is high but the supply is low. So, through this loan, Lucy is going to comfortably meet the demand.

Her increased income will allow Lucy to provide a secure future for her school-going children by paying their tuition fees. She believes that education is the gateway to success. Her vision is to be a leading supplier of bananas in major hotels and households in her region. Help her out!

loans.use: to buy seeds and start banana farming.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 34 years old. He works producing coffee under various certification seals, having worked for National Advisory for Agriculture in Uganda.

Robert is married to Betty. They have been together for five years now and have two children. They struggle to maintain their coffee crop, which is heavily battered by pests.

Robert wants to improve his crops and make them all organic to be able to sell his coffee at a better price and care for the biodiversity on his land. He is very interested in organic production so as not to damage nature, since he believes that he has to conserve the soil fertility for the future of his children.

He wants to build a family house, which is his motivation to struggle each day, since they are now renting, and he wants a better quality of life in all ways.

With the loan, Robert plans to buy purely organic coffee plants and fertilizers. This will allow him to increase his production and get better earnings, to change his family's quality of life. Pictured is Robert and the little boy in the vicinity is his son.

loans.use: to buy organic farm inputs.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 31 years old. She is married and has two children with her spouse. She operates a boutique as well as salon, businesses she has done for 10 years. 

This is her fourth loan from VisionFund Kenya. She will use the loan to buy hair shampoo and relaxer as well as hair extensions as additional stock for her salon.She will also add new stock of dresses for sale in the boutique.

Florence will use profits from the expanded business to open a boutique. 

She hopes and dreams to have a successful business in the future.

loans.use: to buy hair shampoo and relaxer as well as hair extensions as additional stock for her salon.She will also add new stock of dresses for sale in the boutique

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 33 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has two children who are all currently in school. For the past 10 years, Rebecca has been working hard to manage her bar.

To help expand her business, Rebecca has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more drinks for the bar, and will help Rebecca to generate greater profits and have a bigger business. Rebecca hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the business.

Rebecca is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rebecca who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more drinks for the bar.

loans.name: Twisungane Group

texts.en:
Evelyne is 41 years old and is married with three children between the ages of 10 and 17. All of her children go to school. Evelyne is the leader of a loan group called “Twisungane,” which means “let us join.” Group members sell different products and wish to expand their businesses to change their futures for the better. Evelyne has been running a food stall for seven years.

Evelyne is requesting a loan to buy more Irish potatoes to sell. She will use the profit from her loan to pay school fees for her children and to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: to buy Irish potatoes to sell

loans.name: Ddembe Coperative Group

texts.en:
Joweriah is the representative for Ddembe representative group, which is in its first loan cycle with UGAFODE Microfinace Bombo branch. The group is made up of five members, who have different activities such as buying and selling charcoal, selling China made slippers and offering transport services. This loan will benefit each of these micro-businessmen as well as Joweriah.

Joweriah is a food vendor who prepares and sells pan cakes, fried cassava and fried fish. She reports that she learned this business from her mother 12 years ago.

The loan she is currently requesting will allow her to increase her business capital by buying more wheat dough, fish, cooking oil, and cassava, all of which she will use to prepare cassava and fried fish to offer for sale to her customers. As a single mother, Joweriah is grateful that her business allows her to generate income to support herself, educate her child and also support her family members.

loans.use: To buy wheat dough, cassava and cooking oil to boost her business

loans.name: Twubakane Group

texts.en:
Solange is the group leader and is aged 33 years. She is married with four children aged between 5 and 13 years. They all go to school.

The group is called Twubakane, which means “Build Each Other” in English. They sell different products, and they wish to expand their businesses for changing their better future.

Solange owns a bar and has been running a business for seven years. With the loan, she would like to buy more beer for sale. The profits from the business will be used to pay for school for her children and to renovate her house.

loans.use: to buy more beer for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more rice, sugar, biscuits and juice to sell.

loans.name: Bonsong - Kpatari-Bugu Group

texts.en: Kubura is a 36 year-old active woman from Kpataribogu in the Northern part of Ghana. Kubura is married and has five children. She is the person squatting and having a hand placed on the shea nuts in the group picture. Kubura is a member of a shea nut and butter processing group which has been in business over the past three years. Their group is called ‘Bonsong - Kpatari-Bugu’ Women group. She makes good profits from the business since there is a ready market for her shea products. She and every member of her group have been trained by Grameen Ghana on how to process high quality shea nuts and butter for the local and export markets. Kubura and the group have asked for a loan of GHC 4,900 after having completely paid off a previous loan of GHC 2,400. The share of the loan to Kubura of GHC 400 would help her pay for the cost of six bags of shea nuts for extraction of shea butter. By taking the loan, she would increase productivity and thus, pay back this loan and provide for her children’s educational and health needs.

loans.use: To pay for the cost of six bags of shea nuts for extraction of shea butter.

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda is a resident of Adidigweno Boke, Lira district. She is 37 years old. She is a widow and takes care of four boys her husband left her with since he passed away in 2013. Brenda provides financial support to the family and makes sure that her children are schooling.

Brenda runs a clothing sales business in a market in Lira town. She has been in business for seven years. Her business is doing well since there is high demand for clothes in Lira town.

Brenda has future plans to expand her business. She has applied for a loan of UGX 1,500,000 from UGAFODE Microfinance to boost her business, and she is grateful to UGAFODE and to Kiva funders for the great financial support they have given to her.

loans.use: to stock more clothes

loans.name: Riga

texts.en: Riga is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Kiyawa Village. Riga joined Babban Gona to create a better life for his children. In the past, Riga suffered from poor yields that inhibited his ability to increase his farmland. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Riga will have access to the best farm inputs in the market such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the Nigerian national average of 14 bags. This will see him increase his household income considerably. Thanks to Babban Gona's support, Riga now has the opportunity to increase his yields and income and use his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farmers' yields

loans.name: Surajo

texts.en: Surajo is a Babban Gona farmer from Doka Village. He joined Babban Gona so that he could realize better yields on his farm. Since joining Babban Gona, Surajo no longer has to worry about having inadequate income to pay for his children's school fees. Through Babban Gona’s input loan he will have access to top-of-the-range farm inputs such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/ hectare, double the national average in Nigeria.  This will see him increase his income considerably.  This season Surajo has ambitious plans to harvest 45 bags of maize. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Surajo now has the opportunity to purchase a motorbike and do business with it.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farmers' yields

loans.name: Hannah Group

texts.en:
Tsitsi is a 55-year-old mother of four children and a grandmother of five. She runs a poultry business that she started in 1998. Each morning she wakes up to wash the drinkers before putting out a fresh supply of clean water. She is passionate about her business. At times, she would sit for hours, watching the chickens feed and run around. 

Her four children have finished high school education and their school fees were paid using proceeds from her poultry business. Tsitsi recalls the times when she would go to the market and sell her chickens and endure comments from passerbys and council officials. Times were tough and, during those days, men dominated the market. Nowadays, she does not need to go to the market; she supplies different canteens with dressed chickens. She gets paid on her supply within a week, if business is good. 

Now that Tsitsi’s children are able to take care of themselves, her focus is on growing her business. She is applying for a fourth loan from Thrive Microfinance Ltd.. She has been able to extend her fowl-run and increase the number of broilers she keeps at one time. Her group mate, Letwin, is also into the poultry business. They have a good repayment history with Thrive Microfinance.

They hope that a loan from Kiva will help them achieve their ambitions. They plan to increase their scale of production, so that they can be the sole suppliers to the canteens that they deal with. They hope that a Kiva loan will help them realize enough profits to finish building their homes.

loans.use: to extend her fowl-run and the number of chickens she can supply.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase tomatoes, bananas, charcoal

loans.name: Abagambakamu Women Group Kabata Kisomoro

texts.en:
Joseph is a member of Abagambakamu Women Group Kabata Kisomoro, where members guarantee each other for a group loan. He is aged 42 with 3 children and lives in Fort Portal Uganda. He is a farmer growing food crops and at the same time rears cattle for milk production. This is a group that has been paying back well and is taking a loan for the nineteenth time. Most of its members are farmers who have managed to help and develop each other. Joseph is faced with hardships of pests and diseases affecting his crops which has led to poor crop production. Joseph has asked for a loan to buy herbicides to spray pests in his garden. 

The group brought on board men to join them after agreeing on the terms and conditions of the group as per their constitution plus seeing how the women were progressing. However, the biggest number of group members are women.

loans.use: to buy herbicides and spray pests and diseases affecting his crops

loans.name: Wapendwa Self Help Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Veronica. She is 35 years old, married and a mother of three children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2015 to access training on enterprise development so that she can start small enterprises that can earn her a living. 

She has cereal and dairy farming enterprises and the main purpose for applying for this Kiva loan is to add more stock to her grocery business that she started recently. The loan will help her to increase her production and thus be able to pay children's school fees. 

Veronica is very grateful to Kiva and its lenders and promises to pay promptly.

loans.use: To add more stock to her grocery business, thus generating more income to pay her children's school fees

loans.name: Yesu Nti Group

texts.en: Yesu Nti is a group in Accra township, located on the sea shores where the majority of its inhabitants speak Ga, which is the main indigenous language. These three members the group are into a variety of trades like selling mobile phones, phone credit cards, groceries and second hand clothing. Rolland, a 34-year-old member of Yesu Nti, runs a mobile phones and phone credits business. Roland is currently applying for another loan so that he may amplify his business and buy more mobile phones and phone credits with the final goal of satisfying the demands of his many clients. Rolland will sell so that he may have more income to better his life. This group has the ability to work hard and make more profit so that they can reinvest back into their respective businesses.

loans.use: to buy more mobile phones and phone credits with the final goal of satisfying the demands of his many clients.

loans.name: Kenkonzi  Mubuku Women Group

texts.en:
Susan is 48-year-old, married woman with seven children. She is a hardworking member of Kenkonzi Mubuku Women Group, living in Kasese Uganda.

She operates a produce business selling dry beans, peas, rice and maize. Most members in this group are farmers, who grow rice in the irrigation scheme and who have transformed their families and changed their standards of living.

Susan has a dream of buying a maize processing machine so as to process maize flour and sell a finished product. However, she is faced with a challenge of limited capital to reach her business expectations. Susan intends to use the loan to buy maize and beans for selling.

loans.use: to buy maize and beans for selling.

loans.name: Tania Margoth

texts.es:
Tania es una mujer de 42 años de edad, vive con su pareja, tiene 2 hijos de 13 y 14 años y 1 hija de 17 años, y su negocio es la confección de maletines.
Ella es buena madre, emprendedora, independiente, paciente, constate, responsable y muy trabajadora. Su negocio lo realiza en la zona ‘Agua de la vida’ su nombre se debe a que en el lugar se encontraron muchos ojos de agua, vertientes subterráneas. Y, es por esta razón que muchos de los vecinos no cuentan con agua potable, pero sí con agua de vertiente. De clima frio y seco con una temperatura que varía durante el día entre 1-12 grados centígrados.
Tania es de tez morena, ojos pardos, cabello negro largo lo amarrado, baja estatura, complexión física robusta, su lengua materna es el Aymará que habla en familia y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza. Su vida la comparte con su pareja que trabaja en construcción y con su hijo que aún no se encuentra en edad escolar, viven en un cuarto propio construido de ladrillo y cemento con techo de calamina y piso de madera que cuenta con agua de vertiente recogida de tanque, energía eléctrica y no cuenta con alcantarillado. Su negocio es la confección de maletines y prendas de vestir a pedido y por mayor, ella realiza maletines para congresos, seminarios, talleres, etc., actividades dónde los organizadores entregan a los alumnos su maletín con otros materiales de estudio para el desarrollo del mismo, “tengo clientes continuos que me solicitan maletines para sus seminarios y eventos…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que las ventas son por mayor, la desventaja es la falta de capital para la compra de material de confección como; cuerina, cierres, hilos, etc. Su sueño es contar con capital para abastecer sus pedidos, ella desea realizar la compra de material de confección para la confección de 150 maletines. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 10 años que se dedica a esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Tania solicita un préstamo para la compra de material de trabajo para la confección de 150 maletines.
texts.en:
Tania, 42, lives with her partner. They have 2 sons, ages 13 and 14, and a 17-year-old daughter. Tania runs a business making briefcases. She is a good mother and an enterprising, independent, patient, tenacious, responsible, and very hardworking person. Her business is located in the area 'Agua de vida' (Water of Life), who got its name from being a place where lots of waterholes and underground springs are found. Because of this, many residents don't have running water, but they do have spring water. The area has a cold and dry climate with temperatures that vary between 1-12 degrees Celsius during the day.

Tania has a dark complexion, brown eyes, long black hair that she ties back, a short stature, and a robust physique. Her native language is Aymara, which she speaks with her family. She also speaks Spanish from general knowledge and because of her business. Her life is shared with her partner who works in construction and with her son who doesn't go to school yet. They live in a brick and cement room with a corrugated iron roof and a wood floor. They have spring water from a tank and electricity, but they don't have a sewer system.

Tania runs a business making briefcases and garments wholesale and by request. She makes briefcases for conferences, seminars, workshops, etc., activities where the organizers give the students a briefcase with other study materials for development. "I have ongoing customers who request briefcases for their seminars and events," she says. The advantage of her business is that sales are made wholesale. The disadvantage is the lack of funds to buy material, such as imitation leather, zippers, thread, etc.

Tania's dream is to have the resources to fulfill all her orders. She wants to purchase material to make 150 briefcases. This is her first loan cycle with the institution in the 10 years that she's had her business. Because of these reasons, Tania is requesting a loan to buy material to make 150 briefcases.

loans.use: to buy material to make 150 briefcases.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to construct a cowshed.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Hello lenders! Meet Esther, 46, who is based in the Nandihills area of Kenya. This area is the major tea growing region of the country, but it is increasingly emerging as an important dairy farming zone for East Africa. Thousands of farmers are now finding dairy farming a good supplement, if not a substitute, for maize farming. This handsome mother has been practicing mixed farming for the past 16 years, and her primary source of income has been milk and eggs. She passionately loves dairy farming. She enjoys feeding her cows, and milking her cow is her hobby. Waking up every morning to milk her cow is very fulfilling for her.

The biggest challenge she faces is the lack of a proper dairy unit where her cows can feed and rest. Because of this, she has suffered losses through diseases that attack her cows due to the harsh weather conditions. If you are to reap more from cows, you must feed them properly to get high quality milk. She is requesting a loan from Juhudi Kilimo via Kiva lenders to build a modern dairy unit. With the loan, she will be able to increase her milk production, improve her living conditions, and secure the future of her school-going children. Thanks to the support from Juhudi Kilimo and Kiva lenders, she will be able to build this business and become independent.

Esther wants to do everything, but she needs a little help that you can give to her, let her change lives as she’s always dreamed of.

loans.use: to build a modern dairy unit.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To increase her stock of clothes and other goods for sale.

loans.name: Bienvinido

texts.en: Bienvinido is 65 years old, married and lives in Piao, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. He has been selling various spare parts and motor parts supplies. He also operates a motor repair shop that has customers from neighboring places. Bienvinido is glad that he is making good sales and he wants to have more inventory. To finance his needs, he applied for a loan from Paglaum MPC to buy tires and interiors to display in his shop.

loans.use: to buy tires and interiors to display in his shop.

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Hello world, meet an inspirational smallholder farmer by the name of Violet. Born in 1987 in the Nandi region of Kenya, Violet has grown up to be a very hardworking and enterprising woman. Her upbringing was not easy but at least she managed to finish her secondary education.

Violet is currently running a one acre mixed farm in Nandihills with the unwavering contribution of her dear and handsome husband. She keeps dairy cattle that give her milk to sell.

Violet is seeking a loan to purchase land. Twelve years ago she ventured into farming, she has been relying on her husband's farm to run the agribusiness, and still will. However, the business has grown and all the space is totally utilized. With the loan investment, she will acquire additional land to facilitate the growth of her business. Her financial discipline led her to join Simbi Trade Group (made up of farmers who save together and use the savings to access and guarantee the loans of each member). Returns from the investment will go toward loan repayment, setting up the new land and food for her family. She will also use the money to meet all the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: to purchase land to expand her farming business.

loans.name: Priscah

texts.en:
Fifteen years ago Priscah started farming on a small inherited piece of land in Koilot, a remote village in the Nandi hills area of Kenya. Today, this humble mother of six children sells milk, eggs and a variety of food crops. She is a passionate farmer and, because of the immense knowledge she has on farming, she commands a lot of respect from other farmers in her village.

Dairy farming is close to her heart and every day she wakes up to milk her cow and that makes her very proud. Although she makes profits through milk selling, she lacks a proper dairy unit and she is seeking a loan to build a modern dairy unit. Through the loan she will have a humble time milking her cow and also feeding. A good dairy unit provides a good place where cows can relax and also prevent them catching diseases that may arise because of being exposed to harsh weather conditions such as rain.

Priscah believes that through this loan her living conditions will change because she is going to have an increase in milk production. She will save money that she used to spend on treating her cows because she lacked a good dairy unit.
Priscah waits for your kindness.

loans.use: to construct a modern dairy unit.

loans.name: Lorencia

texts.en: Lorencia is a widow from Tudela, Misamis Occidental where she operates a convenience store. She is 51 years old and she makes a living through retailing various consumable items that gives her a monthly income of approximately PHP 10,000 that sufficiently responds to her needs. Her business activity has existed for more than 11 years. Lorencia said that the success of her business is through the financial assistance from Paglaum MPC. Recently, she borrowed an amount to restock her store with consumable goods like noodles, canned goods, milk, sugar, coffee, soft drinks, condiments and others. Lorencia believes that having enough inventory of goods will keep her customers buying at her store.

loans.use: to restock her store with consumable goods like noodles, canned goods, milk, sugar, coffee, soft drinks, condiments and others.

loans.name: Gorredy

texts.en:
Regardless of the great impact that agriculture has on the Kenyan economy, micro-finance institutions (M.F.I.'s) view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition. Juhudi Kilimo is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Kenyan farmers.

Meet Gorredy, an ever-smiling, hardworking, and honest mother who is 42 years of age. She hails from the Nandihills area of Kenya. She is the proud mother of three lovely children. She loves and treasures her children and will go the extra mile to make sure that they are comfortable. Gorredy’s primary source of income has come from selling milk, crop farming, and poultry farming. Through these ventures she has been able to earn a decent income. She is a very determined and dedicated farmer who has been farming for 5 years, and throughout, she has never regretted going into farming.

Although this humble mum has been making profits, not everything has been “a bed of roses." She faces financial challenges, and because the Nandihills area has proven a ready market for cereals, she is kindly seeking a loan to buy cereals for re-sale and thus improve her income.

Gorredy’s upbringing was challenging, and she has faced many economic problems. Still, this ever-smiling mum has been making great improvements, and she believes that through your loan she will be able to realize her goal of improving her living conditions and transforming her life. Through Juhudi Kilimo, Gorredy has received training and she has proven to be honest and disciplined with finances. She intends to fully repay the loan with the profits from her business.

Gorredy is quite visionary and - with her accumulated profits - hopes she will be able to open a large cereal-selling shop that will boost her income and turn her life around.

loans.use: To buy cereals for re-sale.

loans.name: Ever Ready Group

texts.en:
For the last three years, Priviledge has been rearing broilers as a trade. Over the years, she has perfected the art of rearing good broilers and reducing the number of mortalities. Priviledge is the married mother of four school-going children. She lives in Tynwald North in Harare together with her group members.

Priviledge is a member of Ever Ready Group. Along with her group members, she joined Thrive in March 2015 and received business advice. She highlights that she has benefited a lot from the business advice she received during training. As a group, they are grateful and plan to maintain a good relationship with Thrive and its partners.

Priviledge is also an agent for Botle Buhle, a company that sells kitchenware. Priviledge and her group members have applied for a combined loan of 1,900 USD. She wants to use her portion of the loan to add to her number of chickens because she has got a customer who needs many chickens every day.

loans.use: To expand her production of chickens.

loans.name: Carol

texts.en: Carol has been in the direct selling business of wellness products where she is making good sales. She is 32 years old and married with two kids of school age. She's made her direct selling business a full time business after having many customers coming from neighboring towns where she'd been. Despite being busy selling and attending to her business, she's made it a point that she should remain a hands-on mother to her growing kids. This time, Carol has increasing orders so she needs additional capital that she is asking for from Paglaum MPC. The amount of PHP 10,000 will be used to purchase additional inventory of direct selling products.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory of direct selling products.

loans.name: Chineth

texts.en: Chineth is married to a construction worker husband and they have two kids of school age. Her husband's salary cannot suffice for the needs of her family and that makes Chineth find ways where she can be productive. She ventured into the retailing business with the financial assistance of Paglaum MPC. Chineth has managed her good membership with the cooperative and in return, the coop never fails to provide Chineth with the necessary assistance. This time, Chineth is asking for a loan to purchase goods like canned goods, noodles, condiments and confections.

loans.use: to purchase goods like canned goods, noodles, condiments and confections.

loans.name: Irine

texts.en:
Irine, 37, is a small-scale farmer who specializes in mixed farming. She is based in a small village called Kabirirsang, near Nandihills, Kenya. This charming mother has been doing agriculture on her small, fertile piece of land for five years. Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, and crops.

Irine is seeking a loan to buy more land and expand her farm. Her biggest challenge over the years as a farmer has been lack of adequate capital. It is very hard for small farmers to save enough capital for expansion since farming is marred with all sorts of external risks, such as climatic conditions, pests and diseases, political instability, fluctuation of prices and the high costs of inputs. Because of these factors, the sure way farmers can obtain adequate capital is through leveraging their businesses. With your loan investment, Irine is going to expand her farm in order to increase its output. If and when the investment pays off, Irine will plough the profits back into the farm and increase her asset base.

loans.use: to buy land and expand her farming business.

loans.name: Dinah

texts.en:
Dinah is a wife, mother, and farmer with 6 years experience in mixed farming. She lives in Nandihills, Kenya with her three children on a small piece of land that she inherited from her parents. Dinah completed primary school thanks to the financial support and effort of her parents.
